description: The Operational Support and Analysis (OSA) module is one of the certifications in the ITIL® Service Capability work stream. The module focuses on the practical application of OSA practices in order to enable event, incident, request, problem, access, technical, IT operations and application management. The OSA course can teach organizations and individuals how to manage the everyday operation of IT services and gain a better understanding of how to implement the ITIL processes that will enable them to deliver and support services to customers. It also covers issues relating to the people, relationships, procedures and infrastructure technology required to ensure that the organization or programs can provide the high quality and cost effective IT services that are required to meet organizational needs.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.486
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:03.486 --> 00:00:07.842
In this segment, we're going to take
a quick look into what you can expect from

3
00:00:07.842 --> 00:00:09.570
our upcoming ITIL OSA series.

4
00:00:09.570 --> 00:00:11.910
And Terry, thanks for joining us today.

5
00:00:11.910 --> 00:00:15.400
What are some of the topics that
we're going to cover in that series?

6
00:00:15.400 --> 00:00:16.690
>> Well, Operational Support and

7
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:20.050
Analysis is primarily focused
on service operations.

8
00:00:20.050 --> 00:00:22.090
One of the five lifecycle stages.

9
00:00:22.090 --> 00:00:24.470
This course is
an intermediate level course.

10
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:28.460
And it follows a prerequisite,
ITIL foundations.

11
00:00:28.460 --> 00:00:31.200
So what we'll do is we'll review
foundations very briefly.

12
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:33.240
Making sure we got
the right language in play.

13
00:00:33.240 --> 00:00:38.200
And then we'll dive in deep into
the five processes in play.

14
00:00:38.200 --> 00:00:41.850
Incident management, problem management,
event management, access management, and

15
00:00:41.850 --> 00:00:42.490
request fulfillment.

16
00:00:42.490 --> 00:00:45.290
And then we'll look at the people
that get those things done.

17
00:00:45.290 --> 00:00:47.880
And those people are spread

18
00:00:47.880 --> 00:00:51.740
IT operations management, technical
management, applications management and

19
00:00:51.740 --> 00:00:52.930
the service desk.

20
00:00:52.930 --> 00:00:55.950
And of course because it's
operational support and analysis.

21
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:59.700
We'll also be looking about the best ways
to analyze these different processes

22
00:00:59.700 --> 00:01:00.220
and functions.

23
00:01:00.220 --> 00:01:03.350
To make sure that they're
operating at the highest levels.

24
00:01:03.350 --> 00:01:04.160
>> Awesome.
So

25
00:01:04.160 --> 00:01:06.940
who would say is the intended audience for
this series?

26
00:01:06.940 --> 00:01:10.210
Is it, I guess in general,
who would get the most benefit out of it?

27
00:01:10.210 --> 00:01:11.590
>> It's a good question.

28
00:01:11.590 --> 00:01:14.550
Certainly you're gonna get a lot of
valuable information that could go back to

29
00:01:14.550 --> 00:01:17.520
your office space, your work space,
and make some improvements.

30
00:01:17.520 --> 00:01:20.490
Right, ITIL is the best practice for
IT service management.

31
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:23.840
You could certainly take these principles
back into your operational environments.

32
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:28.170
And begin to consider how to
implement these or approve those.

33
00:01:29.220 --> 00:01:31.230
It also is good for the academic study.

34
00:01:31.230 --> 00:01:33.220
We're gonna help you prepare for
an exam as well.

35
00:01:33.220 --> 00:01:35.090
So if you're on a path
towards certification.

36
00:01:35.090 --> 00:01:38.410
Maybe you're seeking the certificate
to be an ITIL expert.

37
00:01:38.410 --> 00:01:40.490
This is gonna be along that path as well.

38
00:01:40.490 --> 00:01:43.260
So we do spend sometime preparing you for
the exam..

39
00:01:43.260 --> 00:01:45.620
And giving you some pointers
on how that exam looks.

40
00:01:45.620 --> 00:01:48.060
So I think it's both for
the practical purposes and

41
00:01:48.060 --> 00:01:50.040
showing you there's lots
of meat on that bone.

42
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:52.240
But if you're on an academic path for
certification.

43
00:01:52.240 --> 00:01:53.760
You're gonna get something
to chew on as well.

44
00:01:53.760 --> 00:01:55.430
>> All right,
well speaking of certification.

45
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:57.210
If you are on that path,

46
00:01:57.210 --> 00:02:00.970
what can somebody who is going down
that road expect from the exam?

47
00:02:00.970 --> 00:02:02.830
How do we get signed up for it?

48
00:02:02.830 --> 00:02:05.160
What should we do as exam takers?

49
00:02:05.160 --> 00:02:06.390
>> Well, good question.

50
00:02:06.390 --> 00:02:09.080
First of all, the exam at the intermediate
level is certainly different than

51
00:02:09.080 --> 00:02:10.400
the foundation exam.

52
00:02:10.400 --> 00:02:13.810
The foundation exam was 40 questions,
one correct answer.

53
00:02:13.810 --> 00:02:15.270
And you had to get 26 out of 40.

54
00:02:15.270 --> 00:02:18.430
65% to get that certificate and
earn that certificate.

55
00:02:18.430 --> 00:02:21.980
At the intermediate level,
you have to perform a little higher.

56
00:02:21.980 --> 00:02:23.590
And it's a bit harder.

57
00:02:23.590 --> 00:02:24.880
There's only eight questions.

58
00:02:24.880 --> 00:02:27.930
Each question is based on
an independent scenario.

59
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:31.952
And the questions have
answers of gradient scoring.

60
00:02:31.952 --> 00:02:35.840
So in other words, you could pick
a level answer is the best answer and

61
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:37.320
get five points credit.

62
00:02:37.320 --> 00:02:40.380
Or pick a question
that's only worth three.

63
00:02:40.380 --> 00:02:44.890
Over eight questions, if the most you
can get in each question is five points.

64
00:02:44.890 --> 00:02:46.630
That's 40 points at maximum.

65
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:49.100
You have to get at least 28 correct.

66
00:02:49.100 --> 00:02:53.190
So, it's not just route
memorization of concepts and words.

67
00:02:53.190 --> 00:02:55.100
Which is such as what foundation was.

68
00:02:55.100 --> 00:02:56.870
You have to apply that knowledge, and

69
00:02:56.870 --> 00:03:00.430
analyze the situation and
apply appropriately.

70
00:03:00.430 --> 00:03:04.700
So therefore, it's a little bit more
challenging, but also pretty realistic.

71
00:03:04.700 --> 00:03:06.300
They're kind of fun actually.

72
00:03:06.300 --> 00:03:08.860
And to be able to take something and
do something with it.

73
00:03:08.860 --> 00:03:10.770
And that's what this
exam expects you to do.

74
00:03:10.770 --> 00:03:14.280
>> All right, well if that sounds like
something that might interest you.

75
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.075
We look forward to seeing
you in our upcoming series.

76
00:03:17.075 --> 00:03:20.614
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry discuss the foundational information that you as an exam taker need to know about the ITIL Operational Support and Analysis(OSA) exam. 00:05:05.781 --> 00:05:08.800

it does show along the left there in

00:05:14.660 --> 00:05:18.190

00:05:18.190 --> 00:05:21.490

As you're going along the line there
you have to one, only one accountable,

586
00:31:20.960 --> 00:31:22.824
but at least one responsible.

587
00:31:22.824 --> 00:31:25.012
Of course, you could have three or
four people, two people.

588
00:31:25.012 --> 00:31:28.072
You can have more than one R, but
you have to have at least one, or

589
00:31:28.072 --> 00:31:29.463
else nothing will get done.

590
00:31:29.463 --> 00:31:32.825
>> [LAUGH] Kind of necessary
component there, right?

591
00:31:32.825 --> 00:31:34.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, I'm accountable and

592
00:31:34.520 --> 00:31:37.345
you're informed, but
who the heck is doing this thing?

593
00:31:37.345 --> 00:31:38.431
[LAUGH]
>> Right.

594
00:31:38.431 --> 00:31:38.974
Exactly.

595
00:31:38.974 --> 00:31:39.600
All right.

596
00:31:39.600 --> 00:31:41.050
Let's look at some other roles.

597
00:31:41.050 --> 00:31:44.480
Now, we've kind of loaded up these words
accountable and responsible, right?

598
00:31:44.480 --> 00:31:47.997
Accountable is make sure it gets done.

599
00:31:47.997 --> 00:31:52.981
So what a process owner is accountable for
is to ensure the process we

600
00:31:52.981 --> 00:31:57.013
formed according to agreed and
documentary process.

601
00:31:57.013 --> 00:31:57.557
Right.

602
00:31:57.557 --> 00:31:59.674
And of course your meeting objectives.

603
00:31:59.674 --> 00:32:04.790
Right, you are also probably auditing
to make sure it's complied with.

604
00:32:04.790 --> 00:32:08.030
You are providing the training,
so now here you're responsible.

605
00:32:08.030 --> 00:32:09.860
You're responsible for the audits.

606
00:32:09.860 --> 00:32:12.170
You're responsible for the training.

607
00:32:12.170 --> 00:32:15.130
You're responsible for
the document definition, right?

608
00:32:15.130 --> 00:32:18.290
You are responsible for
what success looks like, so

609
00:32:18.290 --> 00:32:20.460
you define the key performance indicators.

610
00:32:20.460 --> 00:32:23.399
So accountable for
the overall quality of the process.

611
00:32:24.640 --> 00:32:29.100
Response before these specific
activities that attest to that.

612
00:32:29.100 --> 00:32:33.614
>> Is this typically a project manager
that would probably fall under this?

613
00:32:33.614 --> 00:32:34.522
>> No.
>> No?

614
00:32:34.522 --> 00:32:35.810
>> No, imagine this.

615
00:32:35.810 --> 00:32:39.280
Actually, ITIL describes,
you don't have to imagine so much,

616
00:32:39.280 --> 00:32:41.800
ITIL describes 26 processes.

617
00:32:41.800 --> 00:32:44.918
They deal from strategic processes
through design processes,

618
00:32:44.918 --> 00:32:47.040
on down through the life cycle stages.

619
00:32:47.040 --> 00:32:51.470
Some 26 processes are defined by ITIL.

620
00:32:51.470 --> 00:32:55.755
If you wanna have these processes
at your organization, you're gonna

621
00:32:55.755 --> 00:32:59.775
create a process owner, you're gonna name
a process owner, make this come to life.

622
00:32:59.775 --> 00:33:04.135
Now, Daniel, if what you're saying is
to make this process come to life,

623
00:33:04.135 --> 00:33:09.225
should you take a project management
approach to bring that process alive?

624
00:33:09.225 --> 00:33:11.845
That's a good insight,
it really is, right?

625
00:33:11.845 --> 00:33:15.875
But a process owner and
a project manager are not the same thing.

626
00:33:15.875 --> 00:33:17.520
>> Gotcha, makes sense.

627
00:33:17.520 --> 00:33:21.406
>> Yep, and
we'll certainly reinforce this concept of

628
00:33:21.406 --> 00:33:26.120
project management discipline
as you try to implement ITIL.

629
00:33:26.120 --> 00:33:28.548
It's certainly a good approach,
so pretty insightful.

630
00:33:28.548 --> 00:33:32.780
All right, so that's process owner.

631
00:33:32.780 --> 00:33:36.460
A process manager is a little bit closer
to the day to day operation of this.

632
00:33:36.460 --> 00:33:39.040
They are managing the operational

633
00:33:39.040 --> 00:33:41.050
implementation of the process,
if you will.

634
00:33:41.050 --> 00:33:44.570
So they're instructing
people to execute it now.

635
00:33:44.570 --> 00:33:47.200
Maybe they are practitioners in it well.

636
00:33:47.200 --> 00:33:52.010
So they actually are involved in a day
to day execution, process managers are.

637
00:33:52.010 --> 00:33:53.970
Process owners, accountable.

638
00:33:53.970 --> 00:33:56.420
Process managers, responsible.

639
00:33:56.420 --> 00:34:00.609
And of course, process practitioners are
on the ground carrying out specific steps.

640
00:34:02.060 --> 00:34:07.180
Now, just keep this in mind that this is
not necessarily a hierarchical order in

641
00:34:07.180 --> 00:34:08.400
your organization.

642
00:34:08.400 --> 00:34:11.750
What I mean by that is,
it's possible that a process owner

643
00:34:11.750 --> 00:34:15.890
could be out ranked in your
organization by a process manager.

644
00:34:15.890 --> 00:34:17.010
In fact, it's possible for

645
00:34:17.010 --> 00:34:21.460
a process practitioner to out
rank them as well, right?

646
00:34:21.460 --> 00:34:26.570
For instance, as an example,
in change management, you might require

647
00:34:26.570 --> 00:34:31.310
senior vice president approval for
certain kind of changes, right?

648
00:34:31.310 --> 00:34:33.290
When they go in to approve that change,

649
00:34:33.290 --> 00:34:35.670
they are effectively
a process practitioner.

650
00:34:35.670 --> 00:34:38.030
They are executing steps
within the process.

651
00:34:38.030 --> 00:34:40.140
It has to be the approval process.

652
00:34:40.140 --> 00:34:43.699
So there you'd have a practitioner
potentially out ranking the manager and

653
00:34:43.699 --> 00:34:44.820
the owner.

654
00:34:44.820 --> 00:34:47.761
It's not meant to be
a hierarchical relationship, okay?

655
00:34:47.761 --> 00:34:51.255
All right, a service owner.

656
00:34:51.255 --> 00:34:55.360
Again, we've loaded up these words
accountable and responsible.

657
00:34:55.360 --> 00:34:58.480
A service owner is accountable for
the delivery of the IT service.

658
00:34:58.480 --> 00:35:00.560
They make sure it gets done.

659
00:35:00.560 --> 00:35:03.160
They make sure it gets done well, right?

660
00:35:03.160 --> 00:35:05.722
So they have a stake in the game
of everything that makes a service

661
00:35:05.722 --> 00:35:06.295
successful.

662
00:35:06.295 --> 00:35:09.380
Whether it be processes,
whether it be technology,

663
00:35:09.380 --> 00:35:13.161
whether it be skill sets,
training, customer relationships.

664
00:35:13.161 --> 00:35:16.880
They become the face and
name for the service.

665
00:35:16.880 --> 00:35:17.380
>> Right.

666
00:35:18.900 --> 00:35:23.470
>> So accountable for the entire service,
responsible not so much for

667
00:35:23.470 --> 00:35:25.484
any specific thing, right?

668
00:35:25.484 --> 00:35:30.790
They are accountable holistically for
the quality of the service.

669
00:35:30.790 --> 00:35:31.791
>> Very cool.
>> Yep.

670
00:35:32.793 --> 00:35:35.770
So that concludes our review.

671
00:35:35.770 --> 00:35:38.240
This is a good foundation review here.

672
00:35:39.860 --> 00:35:41.740
Self study and
review is gonna be important for you.

673
00:35:41.740 --> 00:35:46.230
What's next is going to be a dive
in to the service operation life

674
00:35:46.230 --> 00:35:47.902
cycle stage as a whole.

675
00:35:47.902 --> 00:35:51.400
>> Awesome, well, Terry,
I'm looking totally forward to that.

676
00:35:51.400 --> 00:35:53.010
I'm sure our audience is as well.

677
00:35:53.010 --> 00:35:54.760
We do thank you guys for
dropping by today.

678
00:35:54.760 --> 00:35:57.980
You've done a fantastic job of reminding
us of all the key concepts and

679
00:35:57.980 --> 00:36:03.830
things that we are going to assume to be
known by us as exam takers for the OSA.

680
00:36:03.830 --> 00:36:06.570
So definitely crack out your old books,
all your exam notes,

681
00:36:06.570 --> 00:36:09.840
refresh that content in your mind so
that you are prepared for that.

682
00:36:09.840 --> 00:36:12.560
And of course, we're gonna build
upon that foundational knowledge

683
00:36:12.560 --> 00:36:13.880
in our upcoming episodes.

684
00:36:13.880 --> 00:36:14.760
So looking forward to that.

685
00:36:14.760 --> 00:36:16.230
Thanks for dropping by today, Terry.

686
00:36:16.230 --> 00:36:18.960
And thank you guys for watching,
but it is time for us to sign off.

687
00:36:18.960 --> 00:36:21.490
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

688
00:36:21.490 --> 00:36:22.220
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

689
00:36:22.220 --> 00:36:22.758
>> And we'll see you next time.

690
00:36:22.758 --> 00:36:30.935
[MUSIC]

691
00:36:30.935 --> 00:36:33.266
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry explore Incident Management topics covered in the ITIL OSA exam. They start by defining both Incident Management and Incidents proper. They look at being proactive and reactive as well as setting prioritization for incidents. Finally, they cover investigation, diagnosis, and resolution.
episodes.title: Incident Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.950 --> 00:00:06.059
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host

2
00:00:06.059 --> 00:00:10.630
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.490 --> 00:00:14.072
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

4
00:00:14.072 --> 00:00:16.007
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.007 --> 00:00:18.220
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

6
00:00:18.220 --> 00:00:23.370
And in today's episode, we are continuing
on with more on our ITIL OSA series.

7
00:00:23.370 --> 00:00:25.920
And of course, back for
more of that action to lend his

8
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:28.950
expertise on that very topic,
our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

9
00:00:28.950 --> 00:00:30.150
Terry, welcome back, man.

10
00:00:30.150 --> 00:00:30.670
How's it going?

11
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:32.820
>> Glad to be here, Daniel, as usual.

12
00:00:32.820 --> 00:00:35.955
Yeah, we got a pretty good topic
here on incident management.

13
00:00:35.955 --> 00:00:40.250
Incident management is a fundamental
foundational process in service operations

14
00:00:40.250 --> 00:00:43.030
that makes sure you restore
service as quickly as possible.

15
00:00:43.030 --> 00:00:47.170
And it faces end users often,
not always, but often.

16
00:00:47.170 --> 00:00:49.360
Therefore, it's a pretty
important process.

17
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:51.010
>> Well, I guess that being said,

18
00:00:51.010 --> 00:00:55.750
if it's that important, where do we
start to understand this monster?

19
00:00:55.750 --> 00:00:58.790
>> Well, let's first define,
remind ourselves, what an incident is.

20
00:00:58.790 --> 00:01:02.910
An incident really is just
anytime something happens that

21
00:01:02.910 --> 00:01:07.250
could disrupt the service or
has disrupted the service.

22
00:01:07.250 --> 00:01:10.891
So this could be something you're
monitoring in the backend that's not

23
00:01:10.891 --> 00:01:13.349
necessarily visible to users,
such as events.

24
00:01:13.349 --> 00:01:15.320
The disk is 75% full.

25
00:01:16.580 --> 00:01:19.610
So you get in front of that problem,
in front of that failure,

26
00:01:19.610 --> 00:01:22.330
and you solve it before it disrupts.

27
00:01:22.330 --> 00:01:26.078
Or it could be the user calls and says,
the service is down, I can't use it,

28
00:01:26.078 --> 00:01:27.025
what's going on?

29
00:01:27.025 --> 00:01:31.580
Or 50 users call and say,
the service is down, I can't use it.

30
00:01:31.580 --> 00:01:35.959
That's also an incident, or
in that case, probably 50 incidents.

31
00:01:35.959 --> 00:01:37.675
Cuz a lot of people called, right.

32
00:01:37.675 --> 00:01:42.110
So an incident is each occurrence
of the detection, right?

33
00:01:42.110 --> 00:01:45.484
So if 50 people called the service desk,
that would be 50 incidents.

34
00:01:45.484 --> 00:01:49.721
Even though there's probably only
one problem underneath all those 50,

35
00:01:49.721 --> 00:01:53.770
that's still, in terms of units
of measure, that's 50 incidents.

36
00:01:53.770 --> 00:01:55.405
>> That's a good distinction to make.

37
00:01:55.405 --> 00:01:59.012
Cuz if you go in the exam and you think,
well, yeah, we had 50 people call, but

38
00:01:59.012 --> 00:02:01.872
the incident is one,
it's one thing that's causing these calls,

39
00:02:01.872 --> 00:02:04.763
you might be tempted to think
that's one incident, but it's not.

40
00:02:04.763 --> 00:02:08.027
It's each time a user calls in
saying something is occurring,

41
00:02:08.027 --> 00:02:09.770
you count that as an incident.

42
00:02:09.770 --> 00:02:12.830
>> Yeah, you need to keep track,
you need to count these things,

43
00:02:12.830 --> 00:02:15.120
cuz that itself is important data.

44
00:02:15.120 --> 00:02:18.870
The underlying root cause of this ITIL
would call a problem, by the way.

45
00:02:18.870 --> 00:02:22.400
So underneath this is a problem
that's causing these 50 incidents to

46
00:02:22.400 --> 00:02:23.660
occur, right.

47
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:29.600
Or maybe you got 10 today and
20 tomorrow and 35 next week.

48
00:02:29.600 --> 00:02:31.013
So they add up over time, right.

49
00:02:31.013 --> 00:02:33.291
So that's why you keep score.

50
00:02:33.291 --> 00:02:37.404
You're also spending cycles of work
effort trying to resolve those.

51
00:02:37.404 --> 00:02:38.910
That's another reason why you keep score.

52
00:02:38.910 --> 00:02:42.800
You don't just ignore it,
you still log those things.

53
00:02:42.800 --> 00:02:44.852
So that's what an incident is.

54
00:02:44.852 --> 00:02:47.181
So why manage them, right?

55
00:02:47.181 --> 00:02:49.340
So let's have a look at this slide here.

56
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:53.310
Again, the purpose of incident management
is to restore service as quickly

57
00:02:53.310 --> 00:02:53.890
as possible.

58
00:02:53.890 --> 00:03:00.160
So when these things do happen, you get
the service restored quickly, right?

59
00:03:00.160 --> 00:03:04.070
In doing so, you're minimizing the adverse
effects on business operations,

60
00:03:04.070 --> 00:03:06.630
because you're quick at
getting these things restored.

61
00:03:06.630 --> 00:03:11.300
And you get general good guidelines
on how you should be operating,

62
00:03:11.300 --> 00:03:13.770
how quickly, on what types of services.

63
00:03:13.770 --> 00:03:16.490
Some instances may have lower
priorities than others, right?

64
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:21.591
If a user calls and says, I can't find
the submit button on the application,

65
00:03:21.591 --> 00:03:25.673
is that just a user education thing,
or if 50 people call and

66
00:03:25.673 --> 00:03:31.190
say I can't find the submit button, is
that an intrinsic problem with the design?

67
00:03:31.190 --> 00:03:37.220
Or did it go away in the last change over
the weekend and it was an accident, right?

68
00:03:37.220 --> 00:03:39.850
So that's why you keep score,
you keep logging.

69
00:03:39.850 --> 00:03:42.800
And you make sure you're
responding to the right things,

70
00:03:42.800 --> 00:03:45.160
and the right indicators,
at the right time, right.

71
00:03:45.160 --> 00:03:48.770
So why standardize these things?

72
00:03:48.770 --> 00:03:50.760
Standardized methods
means you can repeat it.

73
00:03:50.760 --> 00:03:52.180
You can get efficient at it.

74
00:03:52.180 --> 00:03:53.750
You get methodical about it.

75
00:03:53.750 --> 00:03:56.031
You're not reinventing
the wheel every time, right.

76
00:03:56.031 --> 00:04:00.489
So these incidents could start,
again, the traditional way,

77
00:04:00.489 --> 00:04:03.530
from users calling the service desk.

78
00:04:03.530 --> 00:04:06.125
Or it could be automatically
triggered because of some

79
00:04:06.125 --> 00:04:08.650
event that you monitor
in your infrastructure.

80
00:04:08.650 --> 00:04:12.403
Like there's a disk's 75% full,
sends an alert to somebody.

81
00:04:12.403 --> 00:04:15.595
Or actually raises the ticket,
the incident ticket, and

82
00:04:15.595 --> 00:04:19.520
logs it to the appropriate resolving
team with the right priorities.

83
00:04:19.520 --> 00:04:21.743
That sort of thing.
So some of this could be automated if you

84
00:04:21.743 --> 00:04:25.815
have a robust event management regime,
which we'll be talking in detail about

85
00:04:25.815 --> 00:04:29.260
a little bit later how these
processes can help each other.

86
00:04:29.260 --> 00:04:30.810
So it kind of begs the question,

87
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:36.950
is every incident triggered by
an event which is automated?

88
00:04:36.950 --> 00:04:39.370
No, because users might discover it first.

89
00:04:39.370 --> 00:04:40.080
Right?

90
00:04:40.080 --> 00:04:43.910
Is every event lead to an incident?

91
00:04:43.910 --> 00:04:48.120
No, they are distinct and
different concepts in ITIL.

92
00:04:48.120 --> 00:04:51.290
They certainly are related, but
they are distinct and separate, okay.

93
00:04:51.290 --> 00:04:54.610
So another aspect of any of
these processes, by the way,

94
00:04:54.610 --> 00:04:57.840
as we go through the five
processes of service operations,

95
00:04:57.840 --> 00:05:00.800
we will necessarily be talking about
policy and overall governance.

96
00:05:02.530 --> 00:05:07.190
Policy and process work together to
provide the governance framework.

97
00:05:07.190 --> 00:05:10.880
Along with performing audits,
keeping count,

98
00:05:12.000 --> 00:05:16.670
assessing people's adherence or
compliance with the processes

99
00:05:16.670 --> 00:05:20.960
is also part of the health of a process
and the governance of a process.

100
00:05:20.960 --> 00:05:24.550
But policies, reinforce,
because they're written down,

101
00:05:24.550 --> 00:05:27.030
they're the rules that
you're supposed to follow.

102
00:05:27.030 --> 00:05:29.160
So it's one thing to have a process.

103
00:05:29.160 --> 00:05:33.860
It's another thing for that process
to be bolstered by policy, right.

104
00:05:33.860 --> 00:05:38.148
And these are just some of the examples
of some of the topics that policy could

105
00:05:38.148 --> 00:05:38.820
play in on.

106
00:05:38.820 --> 00:05:43.809
And rather than read all these, I just
want to point out that understanding that

107
00:05:43.809 --> 00:05:48.797
a process doesn't it stands on its own
island and everyone follows it because,

108
00:05:48.797 --> 00:05:50.600
policy helps that, right.

109
00:05:50.600 --> 00:05:53.510
Policy helps that and
enforce the need to comply, right.

110
00:05:54.620 --> 00:05:58.860
As you take an exam, certainly
having policies backing up of your

111
00:06:00.080 --> 00:06:03.650
processes is gonna be one of those
key factors you're looking for.

112
00:06:03.650 --> 00:06:07.231
And perhaps that best answer
that has a five wait,

113
00:06:07.231 --> 00:06:11.930
as opposed to the second best
answer that might leave policy out.

114
00:06:11.930 --> 00:06:16.655
Okay, so the basic principles of incident
management is to make sure you do

115
00:06:16.655 --> 00:06:18.460
things in a timely manner.

116
00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:21.210
If the main purpose of incident
management is to restore

117
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:25.950
service as quickly as possible,
then time is of the essence.

118
00:06:25.950 --> 00:06:31.680
If your tool set can support time scales,
meaning how long it took for

119
00:06:31.680 --> 00:06:35.770
the incident to be detected,
how long did it take for

120
00:06:35.770 --> 00:06:39.240
it to be resolved, right,
and all points in between.

121
00:06:39.240 --> 00:06:42.433
Did it linger with the network team for
two hours before it got transferred

122
00:06:42.433 --> 00:06:45.078
to the server team,
which was really the ones that fixed it?

123
00:06:45.078 --> 00:06:49.067
So did we misdiagnose at the early end of
that and therefore waste two hours of time

124
00:06:49.067 --> 00:06:53.220
with the network team when it should
have gone straight to the server team?

125
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:58.472
So paying attention to this over
time is an important aspect, right.

126
00:06:58.472 --> 00:07:01.235
And coming up with
repeatable processes for

127
00:07:01.235 --> 00:07:04.600
how to handle particular
kind of incidents.

sure enough you see more success and
availability in operations example, right?

545
00:29:25.780 --> 00:29:29.010
So looking for that correlation,
look for the facts and figures.

546
00:29:29.010 --> 00:29:33.480
CSI and
problem management are very synergetic.

547
00:29:33.480 --> 00:29:34.670
They help each other.

548
00:29:34.670 --> 00:29:39.818
If you help proper management, problem
management will help your services.

549
00:29:39.818 --> 00:29:41.750
All right.

550
00:29:41.750 --> 00:29:46.190
You'll recall from incident management
that critical success factors in KPIs,

551
00:29:46.190 --> 00:29:48.300
there's a lot of verbage here.

552
00:29:48.300 --> 00:29:52.490
And I'm not going to spend our
time reading this ferbish to you.

553
00:29:52.490 --> 00:29:56.790
But I don't want to belittle
how important these are.

554
00:29:56.790 --> 00:30:01.300
As a point of review, if you can go to
critical success factors in KPIs and

555
00:30:01.300 --> 00:30:05.800
read then and
quickly assimilate why that's critical and

556
00:30:05.800 --> 00:30:10.980
how those KPIs support that criticality
you're in a good place of understanding.

557
00:30:10.980 --> 00:30:13.240
If on the other hand you read
these critical success factors and

558
00:30:13.240 --> 00:30:15.630
say, hm, I didn't think that was
related to problem management at all,

559
00:30:15.630 --> 00:30:18.490
or I didn't think that was related
to access management at all.

560
00:30:18.490 --> 00:30:20.800
All right,
well then you got some studying to do, or

561
00:30:20.800 --> 00:30:23.400
some questions to ask
the discussion forum.

562
00:30:23.400 --> 00:30:28.210
So rather than read these in minute
detail, I'm always gonna remind you,

563
00:30:28.210 --> 00:30:33.820
read your critical success factors,
read your KPIs as a first point of review.

564
00:30:33.820 --> 00:30:38.880
If you can fully understand how these work
together toward that particular process

565
00:30:38.880 --> 00:30:41.690
you are in a good place of
understanding that process.

566
00:30:41.690 --> 00:30:42.190
>> All right.

567
00:30:44.760 --> 00:30:45.810
>> Of course, there's challenges and

568
00:30:45.810 --> 00:30:49.220
risks to problem management
as there is with any process.

569
00:30:49.220 --> 00:30:50.910
Certainly challenges for

570
00:30:50.910 --> 00:30:54.050
problem management is you have to have
an effective incident management process.

571
00:30:54.050 --> 00:30:56.220
They kind of work together so closely.

572
00:30:56.220 --> 00:30:59.930
If instance management
can not identify things,

573
00:30:59.930 --> 00:31:02.590
then how is problem management
going to know about it.

574
00:31:02.590 --> 00:31:07.440
So it's one of the primary identification
points is incident management,

575
00:31:07.440 --> 00:31:09.820
problem management who should
be in the dark, right?

576
00:31:09.820 --> 00:31:12.430
This requires a stronger level
of capabilities, skills and

577
00:31:12.430 --> 00:31:15.980
capabilities in problem management
are not the same level of skills you have

578
00:31:15.980 --> 00:31:19.210
at the service desk necessarily, right?

579
00:31:19.210 --> 00:31:24.070
The folks that work in problem management
probably need to have a broad and deep

580
00:31:24.070 --> 00:31:28.650
capability to understand the technology
and the services underneath them, right?

581
00:31:28.650 --> 00:31:31.750
All right, let's consider what's next.

582
00:31:31.750 --> 00:31:35.360
I described the critical assess factors
and KPIs as a great place to study.

583
00:31:35.360 --> 00:31:39.210
There's also some directed self-study
in the exercises that you can download.

584
00:31:39.210 --> 00:31:43.400
It takes you about an hour to go
through these, probably a little less.

585
00:31:45.060 --> 00:31:48.120
The very definitive tools here,

586
00:31:48.120 --> 00:31:50.390
that get deeper into those
techniques we talked about.

587
00:31:50.390 --> 00:31:51.950
I showed you a Pareto and

588
00:31:51.950 --> 00:31:56.800
I showed you an Ishikawa diagram, well
those other techniques are also explained.

589
00:31:56.800 --> 00:31:59.280
And you get to walk through
those a little bit.

590
00:31:59.280 --> 00:32:02.050
Highly valuable way to get your head and

591
00:32:02.050 --> 00:32:06.670
your arms around this process
called problem management.

592
00:32:06.670 --> 00:32:08.860
I definitely encourage
your self study there.

593
00:32:08.860 --> 00:32:13.810
As usual come to the discussion forum and
ask questions as you wish.

594
00:32:13.810 --> 00:32:15.150
>> Awesome stuff, Terry.

595
00:32:15.150 --> 00:32:17.880
Man, problem management, there's
a lot of information going on there.

596
00:32:17.880 --> 00:32:21.780
You did a fantastic job of explaining for
us what we need to know, study for

597
00:32:21.780 --> 00:32:25.150
the exam, how to get that down so
that we know that we are prepared for

598
00:32:25.150 --> 00:32:27.130
that exam when we sit in that seat.

599
00:32:27.130 --> 00:32:29.240
That being said, we do thank you for
dropping by today but

600
00:32:29.240 --> 00:32:31.780
it looks like it's that time for
us to sign off.

601
00:32:31.780 --> 00:32:34.540
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

602
00:32:34.540 --> 00:32:35.250
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

603
00:32:35.250 --> 00:32:37.389
>> And we'll see you next time.

604
00:32:37.389 --> 00:32:43.418
[MUSIC]

605
00:32:43.418 --> 00:32:46.689
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry take a look at Event Management as covered in the ITIL OSA exam. They start by defining what Events are, how they differ from Incidents, what's their value, and their categories. Then they describe the process of designing Event Management as well as detecting/filtering/notification, event correlation, triggers, and response.
episodes.title: Event Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.445
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.445 --> 00:00:08.440
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.440 --> 00:00:13.180
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:13.180 --> 00:00:17.040
>> Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:17.040 --> 00:00:18.370
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

6
00:00:18.370 --> 00:00:22.950
in today's episode we are continuing
on with more on ITIL OSA series.

7
00:00:22.950 --> 00:00:25.420
And of course, joining us back in
the studio again today to help us out with

8
00:00:25.420 --> 00:00:27.780
that endeavor is our good friend,
Mr. Terry Decker.

9
00:00:27.780 --> 00:00:29.400
Terry, welcome back my man,
how's it going?

10
00:00:29.400 --> 00:00:30.850
>> As always, happy to be here.

11
00:00:30.850 --> 00:00:33.280
And got a lot to learn, as always.

12
00:00:33.280 --> 00:00:34.910
We've gone through a couple processes.

13
00:00:34.910 --> 00:00:37.850
We've gone through incident management,
we've gone through problem management.

14
00:00:37.850 --> 00:00:42.910
Three more to go, in terms of processes,
we have event management up next.

15
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:46.200
As we did with these others, we need to
know what it is, what is an incident,

16
00:00:46.200 --> 00:00:46.910
what is a problem?

17
00:00:46.910 --> 00:00:49.460
We kind of discern those,
but what is an event?

18
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:53.685
Well, it's not just cake and
ice cream at the end of a long work week.

19
00:00:53.685 --> 00:00:58.260
An event is something that can
be automatically detected.

20
00:00:58.260 --> 00:01:02.400
And perhaps provide a basis of
automation in response to that event.

21
00:01:02.400 --> 00:01:04.390
So let me just throw some examples at you,
and

22
00:01:04.390 --> 00:01:06.830
some of these are probably
fairly intuitive.

23
00:01:07.930 --> 00:01:12.950
If you can detect the disk storage
utilization, the capacity,

24
00:01:12.950 --> 00:01:17.660
and get an event automatically triggered,
that the disk is full.

25
00:01:18.930 --> 00:01:19.910
That's the type of an event.

26
00:01:19.910 --> 00:01:23.730
The disk just filled up, and it perhaps
puts an alert in a log somewhere.

27
00:01:24.870 --> 00:01:26.720
Or logs that event in a log somewhere.

28
00:01:26.720 --> 00:01:30.230
Now you need to put something on
top of that log to automatically

29
00:01:30.230 --> 00:01:34.710
perhaps send out an incident
to a technician to say,

30
00:01:34.710 --> 00:01:39.120
hey get this storage taken care of,
or you can have a warning event.

31
00:01:39.120 --> 00:01:40.120
The disk is 75% full.

32
00:01:40.120 --> 00:01:46.112
Is it an event when I
login in the morning?

33
00:01:46.112 --> 00:01:47.737
You might not think that's an event but

34
00:01:47.737 --> 00:01:50.670
you probably have some awareness
that your logins are logged.

35
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:54.170
When you login,
that's tucked away somewhere.

36
00:01:54.170 --> 00:01:59.140
So events can be just be informational,
and they're automatically detected.

37
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:01.350
The batch file completed successfully.

38
00:02:01.350 --> 00:02:04.500
The backup was successful.

39
00:02:04.500 --> 00:02:06.790
The patch installed successfully.

40
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:11.150
Those things can be logged and
put away for future analysis.

41
00:02:11.150 --> 00:02:13.650
Or to, if you're doing some
troubleshooting it says,

42
00:02:13.650 --> 00:02:15.170
was that backup successful?

43
00:02:15.170 --> 00:02:18.570
You can go to the log and say,
yes, it was, that kind of thing.

44
00:02:18.570 --> 00:02:21.340
So something is important to you,
it's significant to you,

45
00:02:21.340 --> 00:02:24.940
you wanna be able to manage it so
you tuck away information about it.

46
00:02:24.940 --> 00:02:29.050
Or, not just tuck it away perhaps,
you use it in a live environment.

47
00:02:29.050 --> 00:02:31.630
Like I said in the disk space example.

48
00:02:31.630 --> 00:02:34.960
When the disk gets 75%
full that is logged, but

49
00:02:34.960 --> 00:02:38.980
wouldn't be good if it also
sent a text to a technician, or

50
00:02:38.980 --> 00:02:42.840
maybe opened a ticket automatically,
an incident.

51
00:02:42.840 --> 00:02:45.140
And got it routed to
the right server group so

52
00:02:45.140 --> 00:02:49.360
that they could shore that up, delete
some log files, do what they need to do.

53
00:02:49.360 --> 00:02:51.710
So an event is this automatic detection.

54
00:02:51.710 --> 00:02:57.530
Could you detect environmental conditions,
such as temperature in the data center.

55
00:02:57.530 --> 00:03:02.960
Is it an event when the temperature
rises five degrees over an hour?

56
00:03:02.960 --> 00:03:05.340
>> I guarantee you, when that email
goes out, there's an event happening.

57
00:03:05.340 --> 00:03:06.150
>> You have a good point.

58
00:03:06.150 --> 00:03:10.465
>> All the IT people start scattering to
the server closet ASAP when that occurs.

59
00:03:10.465 --> 00:03:13.020
>> Right, so events are detected and

60
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:15.470
they can give you a sense of
the health of your environment.

61
00:03:15.470 --> 00:03:23.299
So coming up with intrusion
detection in a security sphere.

62
00:03:23.299 --> 00:03:26.113
Intrusion detection is
effectively an event,

63
00:03:26.113 --> 00:03:29.780
a very sophisticated event
management correlation engine.

64
00:03:30.880 --> 00:03:34.330
If Terry Decker logs in,
that's event, that's logged.

65
00:03:34.330 --> 00:03:37.110
What if Terry Decker is
logging in simultaneously or

66
00:03:37.110 --> 00:03:42.710
trying to log in simultaneously 50 times
in 17 different geographic locations?

67
00:03:42.710 --> 00:03:46.200
So intrusion detection can see that
kinda have those algorithms in play.

68
00:03:46.200 --> 00:03:50.330
And say we got security issue here, right
because it correlates that information.

69
00:03:50.330 --> 00:03:54.208
So, events is a wide landscape,
it really is.

70
00:03:54.208 --> 00:03:59.579
Events can be covering environmental
issues, security issues, capacity issues.

71
00:04:00.640 --> 00:04:04.870
Licensing issues if you
have a shared licence and

72
00:04:04.870 --> 00:04:09.940
you only have a 100 shared license in
that 98th person logs on maybe an event

73
00:04:09.940 --> 00:04:13.762
pops out saying we'll get close to
a license limit here, that sort of thing.

74
00:04:13.762 --> 00:04:16.600
So events give you the ability to

75
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:21.230
automatically detect things you care
about and perhaps provide a basis for

76
00:04:21.230 --> 00:04:24.690
automating a response to those
things that you care about.

77
00:04:24.690 --> 00:04:29.080
That's what event management is, so does
that mean that every event is an incident?

78
00:04:30.850 --> 00:04:35.030
It does not mean that,
like I said Terry Decker logs in today,

79
00:04:35.030 --> 00:04:38.050
you don't have to call the service
desk because Terry Decker logged in.

80
00:04:38.050 --> 00:04:40.950
If Terry Decker log in 50 times
simultaneously across 17 geographic

81
00:04:40.950 --> 00:04:43.049
locations, maybe we got
something to worry about.

82
00:04:43.049 --> 00:04:43.815
>> Why don't we get eyes on that [LAUGH].

83
00:04:43.815 --> 00:04:47.627
>> Yeah, so
not every event is an incident.

84
00:04:47.627 --> 00:04:51.105
And of course, not every incident
is triggered by an event.

85
00:04:51.105 --> 00:04:54.695
Service desk could get a call from a user
saying I can't find the submit button.

86
00:04:54.695 --> 00:04:56.535
That's probably not
automatically detected.

87
00:04:56.535 --> 00:04:59.405
The missing submit button
is probably not an event

88
00:04:59.405 --> 00:05:00.935
because it's not automatically detected.

89
00:05:00.935 --> 00:05:04.175
It was detected by a user that
called the service desk, etc.

90
00:05:04.175 --> 00:05:07.545
So not all incidents
are triggered by events.

91
00:05:07.545 --> 00:05:12.040
Not all events trigger an incident,
but they can also be closely related.

92
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:13.850
That's why we talk about them separately.

93
00:05:13.850 --> 00:05:15.860
It's a separate type of discipline.

94
00:05:15.860 --> 00:05:19.740
You need to have a good awareness
of what you care about, and

95
00:05:19.740 --> 00:05:22.270
what you want to monitor,
and a good discipline for

96
00:05:22.270 --> 00:05:25.210
reviewing all those events
that you are capturing.

97
00:05:25.210 --> 00:05:28.133
That's what event management is about.

98
00:05:28.133 --> 00:05:29.440
So why have this?

99
00:05:29.440 --> 00:05:33.040
What's the value of
events to the business?

100
00:05:33.040 --> 00:05:37.137
We'll first of all it lets you
enable early detection of incidents.

101
00:05:37.137 --> 00:05:40.603
Like I said, if you get a warning
that the disc is 75% full,

102
00:05:40.603 --> 00:05:45.830
you get warning automatically detected
through your event management system.

103
00:05:45.830 --> 00:05:49.230
Throwing out an incident
to the server team, great.

104
00:05:49.230 --> 00:05:52.140
The server team goes,
takes care of the capacity issue and

105
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:55.770
it's never noticed by the end users
because you got in front of it.

106
00:05:55.770 --> 00:05:59.540
So monitoring and
event are closely related, not the same.

107
00:05:59.540 --> 00:06:02.310
Event management is the detection,
monitoring is

108
00:06:02.310 --> 00:06:04.939
the extra layer of management you
put on top of that detection.

109
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:11.220
So, the value to business effectively
is to get in front of incidents so

110
00:06:11.220 --> 00:06:13.120
that they don't happen and
affect end users.

111
00:06:16.400 --> 00:06:21.320
Policies as with any process,
you need policies to back it up.

112
00:06:21.320 --> 00:06:26.390
Perhaps, the security management regime
is very concerned about logon events.

113
00:06:26.390 --> 00:06:31.060
We have a policy that all logins will
be tucked away into an event log.

114
00:06:31.060 --> 00:06:32.060
We know that happens.

115
00:06:32.060 --> 00:06:37.265
Or access to the HR system
will be monitored and

116
00:06:37.265 --> 00:06:39.390
logged so that event is captured.

117
00:06:39.390 --> 00:06:43.550
So security logging could be under
the auspices of security management,

118
00:06:43.550 --> 00:06:44.800
also driven by policy.

119
00:06:44.800 --> 00:06:46.600
We will log all these things.

120
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:50.720
So again, it's not necessarily an event
that Terry Decker logged in this morning.

121
00:06:50.720 --> 00:06:52.440
But what if it was 3
o'clock in the morning,

122
00:06:52.440 --> 00:06:54.980
the same day there was HR data theft?

123
00:06:54.980 --> 00:06:57.410
Maybe you connect the dots through
all these event managements.

124
00:06:57.410 --> 00:07:02.530
We see Terry Decker logged in, we see he
tried to access this system, was denied.

125
00:07:02.530 --> 00:07:06.150
But then, he got in through this way,
because you have these events log.

126
00:07:06.150 --> 00:07:08.810
So, again,
that's a specialized event management,

127
00:07:08.810 --> 00:07:10.350
because it's related to security.

128
00:07:10.350 --> 00:07:15.610
But you can do this for environmental,
you could do this for capacity,

129
00:07:15.610 --> 00:07:19.640
you could do this for
other things you care about.

130
00:07:19.640 --> 00:07:22.630
Any significance that
you care to identify.

131
00:07:24.010 --> 00:07:29.120
So we've talked about these events
in different levels of importance.

132
00:07:29.120 --> 00:07:32.670
ITIL gives these levels
of importance names.

133
00:07:32.670 --> 00:07:35.600
Informational event,
Terry Decker logged in today.

134
00:07:35.600 --> 00:07:37.590
The batch file completed successfully.

135
00:07:37.590 --> 00:07:38.930
Back up successful.

136
00:07:38.930 --> 00:07:40.510
Restore successful.

137
00:07:40.510 --> 00:07:42.870
Data migrated successfully.

138
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:46.520
You don't need to alert anybody
cuz everything is going as is.

139
00:07:46.520 --> 00:07:50.895
But you've got an event log that
it did go as it's supposed to go.

140
00:07:50.895 --> 00:07:55.501
A warning event, disk is 75% full,
CPU highly utilized,

141
00:07:55.501 --> 00:07:58.166
packets being lost on the network.

142
00:07:58.166 --> 00:08:01.281
Right, so a warning is not necessarily
means you got a breach yet,

143
00:08:01.281 --> 00:08:04.287
you don't necessarily have an issue
you have to respond to, but

144
00:08:04.287 --> 00:08:07.650
it's looking kinda grim, you should
be paying close attention to it.

145
00:08:07.650 --> 00:08:11.450
And then, of course,
an exception event is disk is full,

146
00:08:13.060 --> 00:08:16.420
generator is offline, right,
it's gone down, right.

147
00:08:16.420 --> 00:08:19.829
Talking about environmental issues or
power issues, those kind of things.

148
00:08:21.150 --> 00:08:23.420
CPU is on fire
>> [LAUGH]

149
00:08:23.420 --> 00:08:25.830
>> No, but you get the idea,

150
00:08:25.830 --> 00:08:28.570
an exception event is
you've somehow breached,

151
00:08:28.570 --> 00:08:32.930
you've gone past the point of
acceptable performance or conditions.

152
00:08:34.000 --> 00:08:37.280
Such as Terry Decker
trying to log in 50 times.

153
00:08:37.280 --> 00:08:38.740
In 17 different locations.

154
00:08:38.740 --> 00:08:41.690
That's an exception event, we've got
respond to that, what's going on there.

155
00:08:41.690 --> 00:08:43.136
We're under attack, that sort of thing.

156
00:08:43.136 --> 00:08:49.860
All right, so designing for
event management.

157
00:08:49.860 --> 00:08:54.320
You should certainly consider this
early in the design of a service.

158
00:08:55.400 --> 00:08:59.420
Service design is an early stage
in the life cycle of a service and

159
00:08:59.420 --> 00:09:04.410
you certainly need to consider what events
need to be put in play to make sure you

160
00:09:04.410 --> 00:09:09.810
have your finger on the pulse,
if you will, of your environment.

161
00:09:11.240 --> 00:09:17.900
Instrumentation, perhaps a good analogy
for instrumentation is a car, right.

162
00:09:17.900 --> 00:09:20.060
You have certain information
in front of you in a car.

163
00:09:20.060 --> 00:09:20.940
Instrumentation.

164
00:09:20.940 --> 00:09:23.620
Your dashboard, your instrument panel.

165
00:09:23.620 --> 00:09:27.130
Right?
You can see how fast you're going, you

166
00:09:27.130 --> 00:09:31.060
can see how much fuel is being consumed,
etcetera perhaps even air message.
