00:21:21.663 --> 00:21:23.635
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry move into the area of Request Fulfillment. They begin by defining Request Fulfillment as well as its policies, principles, and concepts. Then they discuss Standardization, Request Logging, Categorization, Prioritization, Authorization, Fulfillment, and Closure.
episodes.title: Request Fulfillment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.011 --> 00:00:02.517
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.517 --> 00:00:08.293
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.293 --> 00:00:12.520
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.520 --> 00:00:13.920
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.920 --> 00:00:17.000
And welcome to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:17.000 --> 00:00:19.614
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

7
00:00:19.614 --> 00:00:22.220
we're moving on with more
on our ITIL OSA series.

8
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:25.730
And of course, joining is in the studio
to lend his expertise on the very topic

9
00:00:25.730 --> 00:00:27.070
is our good friend, Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:27.070 --> 00:00:28.970
Terry, welcome back my man,
how's it going today?

11
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:31.020
>> As always, Daniel, happy to be here.

12
00:00:31.020 --> 00:00:33.150
We've gone through, in previous episodes,

13
00:00:33.150 --> 00:00:36.460
three of the five processes
in service operations.

14
00:00:36.460 --> 00:00:38.990
We've gone through incident management,
we've gone through problem management,

15
00:00:38.990 --> 00:00:41.150
we've gone through event management.

16
00:00:41.150 --> 00:00:44.440
Each providing their own
unique piece of the puzzle

17
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:47.070
to maintain effective operations.

18
00:00:47.070 --> 00:00:49.820
So, next up is request fulfillment.

19
00:00:49.820 --> 00:00:51.720
Request fulfillment, so what is a request?

20
00:00:51.720 --> 00:00:56.210
We had to define events, incidents,
and problems, so what is a request?

21
00:00:57.340 --> 00:01:01.070
Any ideas,
what possibly could be a request, Daniel?

22
00:01:01.070 --> 00:01:02.791
>> Someone asking you to do something.

23
00:01:02.791 --> 00:01:04.160
>> Exactly.
>> [LAUGH]

24
00:01:04.160 --> 00:01:05.890
>> And something asking you do something

25
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:09.430
in a fairly repeatable way,
methodical way.

26
00:01:09.430 --> 00:01:13.300
You need to replace your battery in
your laptop, you need a new mouse,

27
00:01:13.300 --> 00:01:16.330
you need headsets,
you need software installed,

28
00:01:16.330 --> 00:01:19.850
you need access to an application,
these standardized things.

29
00:01:19.850 --> 00:01:23.780
That's the nature of requests,
is they're standardized and repeatable.

30
00:01:23.780 --> 00:01:28.340
Right, they could involve in may
involve some sort of work flow

31
00:01:28.340 --> 00:01:30.210
approval process, etc.

32
00:01:30.210 --> 00:01:35.800
But you standardize these services for
quick reactions, and quick fulfillment.

33
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:37.130
Thus, request fulfillment.

34
00:01:37.130 --> 00:01:41.240
You had a lot cash donation today,
especially at the foundation when we talk

35
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:43.040
about memorizing Using
these various things.

36
00:01:43.040 --> 00:01:45.460
We've got incident management,
we've got problem management,

37
00:01:45.460 --> 00:01:47.280
we've got event management.

38
00:01:47.280 --> 00:01:50.710
Another process is access management,
which we will talk about later.

39
00:01:50.710 --> 00:01:53.470
And here we have requests, but
it's not request management,

40
00:01:53.470 --> 00:01:54.520
it is request fulfillment.

41
00:01:55.958 --> 00:01:57.760
But any rate, whatever the name might be,

42
00:01:57.760 --> 00:02:03.900
it's about managing the aspects of
delivering standardized services.

43
00:02:03.900 --> 00:02:04.880
So, why standardized?

44
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:06.500
Why have methodical,

45
00:02:06.500 --> 00:02:11.080
repeatable approaches to how you fulfill
some of these standard requests?

46
00:02:11.080 --> 00:02:12.280
Why do that?

47
00:02:12.280 --> 00:02:14.410
>> So, that it's, like you said,
is it's repeatable.

48
00:02:14.410 --> 00:02:17.760
If you make it the same way every time,
everybody knows exactly what it is

49
00:02:17.760 --> 00:02:21.690
you're talking about when you use
terminology, or you talk about a process.

50
00:02:21.690 --> 00:02:24.070
Everybody understands that that
process is done a certain way,

51
00:02:24.070 --> 00:02:26.050
because you've seen it done in the past.

52
00:02:26.050 --> 00:02:29.890
And you can look at the,
maybe the documentation or

53
00:02:29.890 --> 00:02:32.820
something on how that's done and
repeat that for yourself.

54
00:02:32.820 --> 00:02:36.730
>> Exactly, and by also,
by wrapping a process around it.

55
00:02:36.730 --> 00:02:41.040
You can do it predictably
at predictable cost,

56
00:02:41.040 --> 00:02:42.630
you can manage capacity appropriately.

57
00:02:42.630 --> 00:02:47.350
So I mean, if you have, do you have
spare batteries for laptops in a cabinet

58
00:02:47.350 --> 00:02:50.720
somewhere, and how many request do
you get for battery replacements?

59
00:02:50.720 --> 00:02:51.560
Right, that sort of things.

60
00:02:51.560 --> 00:02:55.150
So, if you have a methodology
of request fulfillment,

61
00:02:55.150 --> 00:02:59.910
you also have a basis for measuring
the capacity of request fulfillment.

62
00:02:59.910 --> 00:03:01.820
Again, something else you keep score on.

63
00:03:01.820 --> 00:03:06.330
You log incidents, you log problems,
you also log request.

64
00:03:06.330 --> 00:03:08.950
You don't have invisible work,
you have a methodology and

65
00:03:08.950 --> 00:03:11.750
a means of measuring how
effective you are at this.

66
00:03:11.750 --> 00:03:15.270
Ultimately, what you're
trying to do is to make it so

67
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:19.170
users understand how to access
them in a repeatable way.

68
00:03:19.170 --> 00:03:23.020
They know where to go for the batteries,
they know where to go for software, etc.

69
00:03:23.020 --> 00:03:26.080
They know how to get these services,
that's part of requests for film.

70
00:03:26.080 --> 00:03:28.900
So, the points of interface are defined.

71
00:03:28.900 --> 00:03:32.450
The points of interface and work flow,
and approval's are also defined.

72
00:03:32.450 --> 00:03:35.750
That's what we're going to be talking
about over the next several minutes,

73
00:03:35.750 --> 00:03:37.040
related to request form.

74
00:03:37.040 --> 00:03:39.360
Fairly straightforward as we go through.

75
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:46.430
As with other processes,
you have policies in place for instance,

76
00:03:46.430 --> 00:03:52.570
you might have a request fulfillment for
passing out iPads to new employees, right?

77
00:03:52.570 --> 00:03:53.540
I'm a new employee.

78
00:03:53.540 --> 00:03:57.930
I call the service desk and enter, I say,
I would like to request five iPads.

79
00:03:57.930 --> 00:04:01.180
It's coming along Christmas, I wanna
fit out the family with them, right?

80
00:04:01.180 --> 00:04:03.840
So, these policies are in
place to kind of govern it.

81
00:04:03.840 --> 00:04:05.690
You don't just fulfill the process,

82
00:04:05.690 --> 00:04:09.450
you don't just fulfill every request
that comes to the service desk.

83
00:04:09.450 --> 00:04:13.920
Maybe not every employee gets an iPad,
maybe only the sales group does,

84
00:04:13.920 --> 00:04:16.550
or maybe only executives get, etc.

85
00:04:16.550 --> 00:04:19.180
So, policies backing up these processes,
and

86
00:04:19.180 --> 00:04:24.210
coming up with request models for
how you give what to

87
00:04:24.210 --> 00:04:29.560
what people is also part of the governance
of the request fulfillment process.

88
00:04:29.560 --> 00:04:34.885
Intrinsic to request is approval, right?

89
00:04:34.885 --> 00:04:39.245
Maybe everyone is pre-approved,
or self approved.

90
00:04:39.245 --> 00:04:42.635
If their battery's not working,
they can request a new battery, and

91
00:04:42.635 --> 00:04:48.625
no magic credit card has to be presented
or no cost center adjustments,

92
00:04:48.625 --> 00:04:52.145
it's just checked and managed in
the background without any issues,

93
00:04:52.145 --> 00:04:54.715
on behalf of the person
that's making the request.

94
00:04:54.715 --> 00:04:57.960
Other things may require a bit
more due diligence, such as,

95
00:04:57.960 --> 00:05:01.630
perhaps the request for an iPad.

96
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:04.072
It's a bit more expensive,
not everyone is supposed to get them.

97
00:05:04.072 --> 00:05:07.880
So, there's more due diligence
applied to those types of requests.

98
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:10.150
That's what request models
are going to help you with.

99
00:05:10.150 --> 00:05:12.650
They are going to define how you approach,
and

100
00:05:12.650 --> 00:05:15.670
how you fulfill certain kinds of requests.

101
00:05:15.670 --> 00:05:18.640
Or what if an executive asks for
software to be installed.

102
00:05:18.640 --> 00:05:23.580
Do you treat the executive differently
than you might treat the end users,

103
00:05:23.580 --> 00:05:24.850
the base users if you will?

104
00:05:26.020 --> 00:05:31.580
Maybe you have request models for
executive requests that are different than

105
00:05:31.580 --> 00:05:35.660
the request models for rank and
file users, as examples.

106
00:05:35.660 --> 00:05:38.620
So, the way we approach this,

107
00:05:40.370 --> 00:05:44.210
how are you going to manage
requests over their life cycle?

108
00:05:44.210 --> 00:05:46.860
Logging them,
making sure you know when they started,

109
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:50.870
what workflow happens in between, and
of course how they end up, right?

110
00:05:50.870 --> 00:05:53.310
That's what request
filament needs to govern.

111
00:05:53.310 --> 00:05:54.910
They need to get on top of this.

112
00:05:54.910 --> 00:05:58.100
Be aware of all the requests as
they come in, log these things.

113
00:05:58.100 --> 00:06:01.690
Provide metrics against
those requests over time.

114
00:06:01.690 --> 00:06:06.931
Right, the idea of self help, if you look
at here, just a brief little graphic here.

115
00:06:06.931 --> 00:06:10.590
A self help, what if you
automated some of these things?

116
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:13.814
You go to web interface, and
you request what you want.

117
00:06:13.814 --> 00:06:16.424
You don't necessarily have
to call the service desk.

118
00:06:16.424 --> 00:06:18.870
Now, the service desk is
a single point of contact,

119
00:06:18.870 --> 00:06:23.850
and the service desk is often a place
where people go to log incidents.

120
00:06:23.850 --> 00:06:27.290
It's also a place where
people go to make requests.

121
00:06:27.290 --> 00:06:30.490
But you also could put some self help
engines in front of this, right?

122
00:06:30.490 --> 00:06:32.340
Maybe it's a web form that they fill out.

123
00:06:32.340 --> 00:06:33.720
And when they click submit,

124
00:06:33.720 --> 00:06:39.030
it goes to the appropriate group of people
that can take care of that request.

125
00:06:39.030 --> 00:06:42.150
Certainly, maybe the people passing out
iPads are not the same group of people

126
00:06:42.150 --> 00:06:44.660
that replace batteries, or pass out mice.

127
00:06:44.660 --> 00:06:46.670
Right, because they had
different request models.

128
00:06:46.670 --> 00:06:47.610
They're might be bit different.

129
00:06:48.650 --> 00:06:50.970
Different parts of
the organization fulfill it.

130
00:06:50.970 --> 00:06:54.970
So, coming up with some self help tools
up in front of the request fulfillment

131
00:06:54.970 --> 00:06:57.160
process can be very helpful.

132
00:06:57.160 --> 00:07:02.030
As this plays out in on your exam,
it's not telling you that

133
00:07:02.030 --> 00:07:05.312
you must have a self help engine
in front of request fulfillment.

134
00:07:05.312 --> 00:07:09.000
It's not telling you that all requests
must go to the service desk, either.

135
00:07:09.000 --> 00:07:12.010
What you need to be looking for
is the methodological approach for

136
00:07:12.010 --> 00:07:14.760
handling the standard
delivery of services, or

137
00:07:14.760 --> 00:07:17.980
the delivery of standard service
might be a better way to put that.

138
00:07:17.980 --> 00:07:23.570
Self help is one of those things that is
highly recommended, because it can save

139
00:07:23.570 --> 00:07:28.200
service desk personnel the time of dealing
with it, they don't have things on behalf

140
00:07:28.200 --> 00:07:33.010
of the user, the user can help themselves
to putting in all those parameters.

141
00:07:33.010 --> 00:07:33.590
And keep in mind,

142
00:07:33.590 --> 00:07:37.790
that it's not necessarily end users that
are being effected by request fulfillment,

143
00:07:37.790 --> 00:07:40.000
it could be IT for IT.

144
00:07:40.000 --> 00:07:45.850
The application team may request from
the server team a virtual server,

145
00:07:45.850 --> 00:07:49.360
or a database to be built,
those kinds of things.

146
00:07:49.360 --> 00:07:53.262
So, request fulfillment can be for
standard services, absolutely.

147
00:07:53.262 --> 00:07:57.852
But those standard services could be
from a supporting service to a customer

148
00:07:57.852 --> 00:07:58.936
facing service.

149
00:07:58.936 --> 00:08:02.231
So, it kinda can bend within IT as well.

150
00:08:02.231 --> 00:08:06.570
Lots of advantages come from
this standardization approach.

151
00:08:06.570 --> 00:08:09.760
Lots of advantages come
from a methodical approach.

152
00:08:09.760 --> 00:08:11.890
You get a control and you get measurement.

153
00:08:11.890 --> 00:08:16.210
That's really what these
processes focus on, okay?

154
00:08:17.670 --> 00:08:22.580
So as you go through these processes,
there's always some sort of flow.

155
00:08:22.580 --> 00:08:27.480
As it relates to request fulfillment,
the workflow could include a stop off for

156
00:08:27.480 --> 00:08:28.650
approval somewhere.

157
00:08:28.650 --> 00:08:32.610
Maybe a manager has to
approve requests over,

158
00:08:32.610 --> 00:08:35.260
and then some threshold of money, right.

159
00:08:35.260 --> 00:08:39.000
If it costs more than $50,
it must have management approval,

160
00:08:39.000 --> 00:08:43.148
you could have that in your policy,
so you build that into the workflow.

161
00:08:43.148 --> 00:08:46.059
Request fulfillment needs to
understand those flows and

162
00:08:46.059 --> 00:08:50.058
come up with the appropriate models to
make sure that the appropriate approval

163
00:08:50.058 --> 00:08:52.014
points are included, if necessary.

164
00:08:52.014 --> 00:08:53.159
All right.

165
00:08:53.159 --> 00:08:54.043
Pretty straightforward.

166
00:08:54.043 --> 00:09:00.260
Doing this,
doing it well is what ITIL encourages.

167
00:09:00.260 --> 00:09:04.807
And by standardizing it and putting a
process owner on top of it to manage your

168
00:09:04.807 --> 00:09:09.620
on-going improvement of it,
you're going to be more successful.

169
00:09:09.620 --> 00:09:14.940
So as it relates to the exam, as you
consider this topic as relates to exam,

170
00:09:14.940 --> 00:09:17.390
obviously, know the difference
between a request and an incident.

171
00:09:19.390 --> 00:09:22.525
For instance, if a user calls to
help desk, or service desk, and

172
00:09:22.525 --> 00:09:24.980
says I can't find the submit button.

173
00:09:24.980 --> 00:09:26.840
Maybe you call that a request.

174
00:09:26.840 --> 00:09:29.020
It's a request for information.

175
00:09:29.020 --> 00:09:30.790
Maybe you call it an incident.

176
00:09:30.790 --> 00:09:34.570
And again, as we talked about that one in
incident management, if 50 people call

177
00:09:34.570 --> 00:09:38.190
the service desk with a submit button,
you got a different issue going on there.

178
00:09:38.190 --> 00:09:40.210
So that's probably not a request.

179
00:09:40.210 --> 00:09:42.870
That's why you need to have
well defined incident models,

180
00:09:42.870 --> 00:09:44.690
well defined request models.

181
00:09:44.690 --> 00:09:47.668
I'm not saying there's a right
answer to this question.

182
00:09:47.668 --> 00:09:50.910
Is that a request or an incident if
the user can't find a submit button?

183
00:09:50.910 --> 00:09:52.460
There's not one right answer.

184
00:09:52.460 --> 00:09:53.622
What you're looking for for

185
00:09:53.622 --> 00:09:56.683
request fulfillment is something
that's standardized and repeatable.

186
00:09:56.683 --> 00:10:01.764
And helping users with questions
like I can't find, is repeatable.

187
00:10:01.764 --> 00:10:03.872
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> And coming up with a approach.

188
00:10:03.872 --> 00:10:04.429
Yes, Daniel?

189
00:10:04.429 --> 00:10:07.839
>> Terry, I'm thinking about this, and
kind of wrapping my brain around it here

190
00:10:07.839 --> 00:10:10.410
and going to that whole
submit button scenario.

191
00:10:10.410 --> 00:10:14.330
Would you say that maybe
an incident is the user calls,

192
00:10:14.330 --> 00:10:17.250
there should be a submit button
there they can't find it, it's gone.

193
00:10:17.250 --> 00:10:21.020
Where as a request would be man it'd be
great to have a submit button right here,

194
00:10:21.020 --> 00:10:22.470
it sure would make our
lives a whole lot easier.

195
00:10:22.470 --> 00:10:23.859
That would be more of a request.

196
00:10:23.859 --> 00:10:27.810
>> Interesting, very good example and
points to a very interesting topic here.

197
00:10:27.810 --> 00:10:31.850
Can a request such as for
request fulfillment,

198
00:10:31.850 --> 00:10:34.785
can it lead to a change being made?

199
00:10:34.785 --> 00:10:37.727
Absolutely, let's draw
some distinctions here.

200
00:10:37.727 --> 00:10:39.070
A very good segue, Daniel.

201
00:10:40.720 --> 00:10:44.000
Remember in change management
back in Foundations,

202
00:10:44.000 --> 00:10:45.440
we learned that there's
three types of changes.

203
00:10:45.440 --> 00:10:48.920
There is a standard change,
an emergency change and a normal change.

204
00:10:48.920 --> 00:10:53.493
Now a standard change is a change
that goes through the change of

205
00:10:53.493 --> 00:10:56.953
approval process one
time to get fully vetted.

206
00:10:56.953 --> 00:11:01.568
And after it's been fully vetted,
a standard change can be integrated any

207
00:11:01.568 --> 00:11:06.560
number of times after that without going
back through that process of approval.

208
00:11:06.560 --> 00:11:12.660
So we use some examples back in about
maybe a standard change could include,

209
00:11:12.660 --> 00:11:17.250
you need updated database
with more table space.

210
00:11:17.250 --> 00:11:19.150
It's a fairly repeatable process.

211
00:11:19.150 --> 00:11:21.090
It's understood how it's
supposed to happen.

212
00:11:21.090 --> 00:11:22.060
You know how it's tested.

213
00:11:22.060 --> 00:11:23.026
You know how it's verified.

214
00:11:23.026 --> 00:11:26.470
So when you need more table space,
don't go back to the CAB.

215
00:11:26.470 --> 00:11:29.320
Don't go back to change advisory board for
approval.

216
00:11:29.320 --> 00:11:30.620
You've got it approved once.

217
00:11:30.620 --> 00:11:32.320
Go ahead and implement it.

218
00:11:32.320 --> 00:11:34.994
So that's the standard change, got it?

219
00:11:34.994 --> 00:11:39.000
Now, some standard changes
could have in front of them

220
00:11:39.000 --> 00:11:42.380
a request fulfillment process.

221
00:11:42.380 --> 00:11:44.250
So for instance,
I need software installed.

222
00:11:45.640 --> 00:11:48.141
Software installation is a change, right?

223
00:11:48.141 --> 00:11:52.608
But you've standardized this software
installation change, meaning you don't

224
00:11:52.608 --> 00:11:56.450
have to go back for approval, so
you put a request engine in front of it.

225
00:11:56.450 --> 00:12:01.710
Now, back to the submit button,
requesting new functionality,

226
00:12:01.710 --> 00:12:05.830
like the addition of a submit button,
is probably not a standard thing.

227
00:12:05.830 --> 00:12:09.300
We don't just change application
interfaces without going through

228
00:12:09.300 --> 00:12:12.010
a full vetting process and
full testing process.

229
00:12:12.010 --> 00:12:14.600
So it's a really good distinction between

230
00:12:14.600 --> 00:12:17.920
that you could have requests
in front of a standard change.

231
00:12:19.140 --> 00:12:22.780
Not all standard changes need to have a
request to fill a process in front of him.

232
00:12:23.810 --> 00:12:29.530
And not all requests necessarily result in
a technical change being executed, right?

233
00:12:29.530 --> 00:12:32.570
So very good distinctions,
very good segue.

234
00:12:32.570 --> 00:12:36.650
And a way to keep good fences and good
neighbors among these processes, right?

235
00:12:36.650 --> 00:12:38.780
Which, of course,
ITIL wants you to find well.

236
00:12:38.780 --> 00:12:40.640
Making sure you know where
one process ends and

237
00:12:40.640 --> 00:12:45.480
another process picks up is an important
aspect of your process modeling.

238
00:12:45.480 --> 00:12:46.700
Very good.

239
00:12:46.700 --> 00:12:49.051
All right, so
let's have a look at a few things here.

240
00:12:49.051 --> 00:12:51.049
First of all, you're going to be logging,

241
00:12:51.049 --> 00:12:54.650
coming up with an information system
that can keep up with your request.

242
00:12:54.650 --> 00:12:56.040
It's not unusual for

243
00:12:56.040 --> 00:13:00.400
request to be logged in the same
place that incidents are logged.

244
00:13:00.400 --> 00:13:01.488
It's not unusual.

245
00:13:01.488 --> 00:13:03.743
It could be that they're
completely separate.

246
00:13:03.743 --> 00:13:07.203
If they're within the same, they're
certainly going to distinguish these two.

247
00:13:07.203 --> 00:13:09.270
It's not the same as an incident.

248
00:13:09.270 --> 00:13:14.430
So you're going to manage the identifier
request separately from an incident,

249
00:13:14.430 --> 00:13:16.360
even if you're using the same tool set.

250
00:13:18.130 --> 00:13:19.380
Is it a valid request?

251
00:13:21.140 --> 00:13:24.270
If I call and say,
I want access to the HR database

252
00:13:24.270 --> 00:13:28.340
because I wanna see everyone's salaries,
is that a valid request?

253
00:13:28.340 --> 00:13:29.400
>> I'll say yes for me.

254
00:13:29.400 --> 00:13:30.740
>> Well, maybe it is.

255
00:13:30.740 --> 00:13:33.545
Maybe Daniel,
you're the new compensation analyst and

256
00:13:33.545 --> 00:13:35.650
are supposed to have access to it.

257
00:13:35.650 --> 00:13:40.032
Or perhaps you're just a rogue trying to
spy on other people's private information.

258
00:13:40.032 --> 00:13:41.361
So that's what validation is about.

259
00:13:41.361 --> 00:13:43.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> Request validation,

260
00:13:43.370 --> 00:13:46.000
is it an appropriate
request to made in general?

261
00:13:46.000 --> 00:13:49.075
Or I call the service desk,
I want five iPads.

262
00:13:49.075 --> 00:13:54.767
Or I call the server team and
say I want five virtual servers and

263
00:13:54.767 --> 00:13:59.970
I need them to have 16 gigs
of memory each, right?

264
00:13:59.970 --> 00:14:01.250
Is that a valid request?

265
00:14:01.250 --> 00:14:02.770
That kind of thing.

266
00:14:02.770 --> 00:14:06.160
The request validation part is simply,
is this legitimate?

267
00:14:06.160 --> 00:14:09.200
Is this something that can
legitimately be fulfilled, right?

268
00:14:09.200 --> 00:14:11.481
Because not all requests are fulfillable.

269
00:14:11.481 --> 00:14:14.256
>> So if I put in a request for
a Gulf Stream G5,

270
00:14:14.256 --> 00:14:16.891
might not be actually mission critical.

271
00:14:16.891 --> 00:14:19.500
>> Exactly, maybe no that's right.

272
00:14:19.500 --> 00:14:22.345
Or it could be such a cost point,
for a good example,

273
00:14:22.345 --> 00:14:24.231
it's just prohibitive, right?

274
00:14:24.231 --> 00:14:29.174
So again, your policies along with your
request models are going to define what's

275
00:14:29.174 --> 00:14:30.030
legitimate.

276
00:14:30.030 --> 00:14:31.120
>> That's right.

277
00:14:31.120 --> 00:14:35.110
>> Of course, categorize them and
keep up with priorities.

278
00:14:35.110 --> 00:14:37.770
Measure the speed at which
you fulfill these, right?

279
00:14:37.770 --> 00:14:41.860
So by having a process in place,
having a methodical approaches

280
00:14:41.860 --> 00:14:44.810
to managing these is going to give
you the ability to control them.

281
00:14:45.870 --> 00:14:46.890
Which is what the goals are.

282
00:14:48.270 --> 00:14:53.110
Again, request authorization can
happen at a couple of levels.

283
00:14:53.110 --> 00:14:56.100
One, it could just be related
to security issues, right?

284
00:14:56.100 --> 00:14:59.780
Are you supposed to have
access to this HR data, right?

285
00:14:59.780 --> 00:15:03.530
And also financial managements is
other aspect of authorization.

286
00:15:03.530 --> 00:15:06.010
Again, if you've worked in environments
that has some sort of threshold,

287
00:15:06.010 --> 00:15:10.550
if it was less than $50, you didn't
have to get management approval, right?

288
00:15:10.550 --> 00:15:13.085
Even that might be prohibited in some
environments cuz people order a headset

289
00:15:13.085 --> 00:15:14.879
everyday and
they pass them out to the family, right?

290
00:15:14.879 --> 00:15:17.829
So it'd have to be some controls in place,
perhaps, for

291
00:15:17.829 --> 00:15:21.570
the number of requests you can
make that meet that threshold.

292
00:15:21.570 --> 00:15:24.230
But certainly if I wanted to start,
I remember this worked out

293
00:15:24.230 --> 00:15:27.470
quite well the standard desktop build
had Microsoft Office for instance.

294
00:15:27.470 --> 00:15:30.700
But I needed access in project management,
right?

295
00:15:31.860 --> 00:15:35.962
The combination cost upwards of $300 or
something like that, so

296
00:15:35.962 --> 00:15:38.590
I had to get a management approval for
that.

297
00:15:38.590 --> 00:15:42.426
Fortunately, the request tool, the ones
where I requested the software that I

298
00:15:42.426 --> 00:15:45.929
wanted, it had a way to email my boss and
get his approval through email.

299
00:15:45.929 --> 00:15:48.914
So coming up with some
self-help automation for

300
00:15:48.914 --> 00:15:54.390
request fulfillment could also be a way to
streamline this process effectively, okay?

301
00:15:56.622 --> 00:16:01.171
Again, straight forward with
the Validation and financial approval, and

302
00:16:01.171 --> 00:16:03.460
then you get the review, right?

303
00:16:03.460 --> 00:16:06.990
The review is okay,
I see you have requested this, great.

304
00:16:06.990 --> 00:16:09.470
Your boss says you can have it,
now let's look.

305
00:16:09.470 --> 00:16:12.940
Okay, you need access, you need project,
you even wanted this thing installed,

306
00:16:12.940 --> 00:16:13.770
this thing installed.

307
00:16:13.770 --> 00:16:17.190
We've got the appropriate approvals,
okay, I'll execute all of that, right?

308
00:16:17.190 --> 00:16:19.760
So, this review port
is just the part where

309
00:16:19.760 --> 00:16:23.700
you're actually looking at the details,
and going to make it happen.

310
00:16:23.700 --> 00:16:28.260
Or if I requested a server to be built,
a virtual server to be provided for

311
00:16:28.260 --> 00:16:31.020
me, getting to request reviews,
gonna get to the details,

312
00:16:31.020 --> 00:16:34.170
what specifications I'm gonna
have to have for this, right?

313
00:16:34.170 --> 00:16:36.640
And of course, eventually execution.

314
00:16:36.640 --> 00:16:42.610
Having the ability to reject a request
should also be part of the workflow.

315
00:16:42.610 --> 00:16:46.660
And having the ability potentially
to reopen the same request,

316
00:16:46.660 --> 00:16:48.110
could be effective.

317
00:16:48.110 --> 00:16:50.990
I recall once, just as an example,

318
00:16:50.990 --> 00:16:55.020
I requested the install
of mind mapping software.

319
00:16:55.020 --> 00:16:56.830
I forget what the name of it was.

320
00:16:56.830 --> 00:17:00.470
And my manager saw that I actually
requested the wrong version.

321
00:17:00.470 --> 00:17:03.520
So, the work flow didn't
give him a chance to say,

322
00:17:03.520 --> 00:17:07.540
ops wrong version,
he just had to reject it, right?

323
00:17:07.540 --> 00:17:11.290
So, that particular installation
was part of a big request for

324
00:17:11.290 --> 00:17:15.900
access, for project,
for mind mapping, etc.

325
00:17:15.900 --> 00:17:17.840
Could I just reopen it and
change the version of it?

326
00:17:17.840 --> 00:17:19.082
That would be convenient for me.

327
00:17:19.082 --> 00:17:23.060
Right, in that particular case, I
couldn't, I had to start a new request and

328
00:17:23.060 --> 00:17:24.410
add everything into it.

329
00:17:24.410 --> 00:17:25.799
So you see, the level of pain,

330
00:17:25.799 --> 00:17:29.547
the level of gain, you need to manage that
in request fulfillment process as well.

331
00:17:29.547 --> 00:17:34.773
The ability to reopen a rejected request
could be a nice way to streamline some of

332
00:17:34.773 --> 00:17:40.558
these things, especially if the request is
for something of some level of complexity.

333
00:17:40.558 --> 00:17:44.188
Cuz you don't wanna put that burden back
on the user to respecify everything,

334
00:17:44.188 --> 00:17:45.680
which points to another thing.

335
00:17:45.680 --> 00:17:46.850
It should be easy.

336
00:17:46.850 --> 00:17:49.605
Right, I've certainly filled out forms
where I don't even know what information

337
00:17:49.605 --> 00:17:50.600
they're looking for there.

338
00:17:50.600 --> 00:17:53.010
And it says it's required.

339
00:17:53.010 --> 00:17:55.130
So now, I gotta call someone, says,
what are you looking for here?

340
00:17:55.130 --> 00:17:59.410
All of a sudden, you're interjecting
pain into the process instead of gain.

341
00:18:00.510 --> 00:18:01.860
So, that's the nature of the beast.

342
00:18:01.860 --> 00:18:05.390
As you take this approach on exams,
you're gonna be looking for

343
00:18:05.390 --> 00:18:09.220
things like the governance,
what models do you have in place?

344
00:18:09.220 --> 00:18:10.510
What approval mechanisms?

345
00:18:10.510 --> 00:18:12.730
Do you allow for self-help?

346
00:18:12.730 --> 00:18:15.453
Right, I'm not saying those
are the right answers necessarily, but

347
00:18:15.453 --> 00:18:17.080
that's how you can approve the process.

348
00:18:19.290 --> 00:18:22.593
Streamline it through self-help,
streamline it through request models, so

349
00:18:22.593 --> 00:18:25.170
that they're repeatable and
understood by everyone, etc.

350
00:18:25.170 --> 00:18:26.250
All right?

351
00:18:28.820 --> 00:18:31.200
Of course, you also need to
consider what CI's are impacted.

352
00:18:32.370 --> 00:18:33.920
Who touches these things?

353
00:18:33.920 --> 00:18:36.280
Does it require a change process?

354
00:18:36.280 --> 00:18:40.490
As Daniel pointed out,
you want to add a submit button?

355
00:18:40.490 --> 00:18:43.690
You know what, that's probably a bit
more complex in putting a request

356
00:18:43.690 --> 00:18:44.550
engine in front of it.

357
00:18:44.550 --> 00:18:47.330
It's not necessary repeatable,
but if it is for

358
00:18:47.330 --> 00:18:51.040
a standard change,
you can definitely get some benefits for

359
00:18:51.040 --> 00:18:53.830
putting a request engine in
front of the standard change.

360
00:18:53.830 --> 00:18:59.550
All right, so,
could you update the currency rates?

361
00:18:59.550 --> 00:19:04.180
Because we need to manage
foreign currencies in here.

362
00:19:04.180 --> 00:19:07.060
So again, we've gone through the cab
before about these currency changes.

363
00:19:07.060 --> 00:19:11.100
We're just changing one field in
a database, changing a number, and

364
00:19:11.100 --> 00:19:12.350
we have a way to test it.

365
00:19:12.350 --> 00:19:14.090
So, put some request
inches in front of that.

366
00:19:14.090 --> 00:19:18.810
So, when the Germans in your organization,
the German geography,

367
00:19:18.810 --> 00:19:22.680
wants to change the currency rate,
it's gone through some reviews.

368
00:19:22.680 --> 00:19:23.767
They request it,

369
00:19:23.767 --> 00:19:28.629
it goes through a normal process of
vetting that it's a valid request, right?

370
00:19:28.629 --> 00:19:31.945
And then make the change without going
through change management in full,

371
00:19:31.945 --> 00:19:32.478
all right?

372
00:19:32.478 --> 00:19:37.140
So, that's the reason why you put CI
analysis in your request fulfillment

373
00:19:37.140 --> 00:19:42.329
process, is so you touch the right things
and keep your hands off the other things.

374
00:19:43.960 --> 00:19:47.990
Good, of course, eventually, you close.

375
00:19:47.990 --> 00:19:52.170
You close off the request, and
make sure everything is tied up.

376
00:19:52.170 --> 00:19:56.530
And again, if the service desk
is in the front end of this,

377
00:19:56.530 --> 00:19:58.189
the service desk should
be there at closure.

378
00:19:59.200 --> 00:20:02.940
If you have a self-help system, obviously
you are trying to automate this interface

379
00:20:02.940 --> 00:20:06.346
with the users,
which is totally legitimate, right?

380
00:20:06.346 --> 00:20:09.638
If the service desk is
involved with the opening,

381
00:20:09.638 --> 00:20:13.341
they should be involved with the closing,
and that could be the way you go about it.

382
00:20:13.341 --> 00:20:16.310
Another approach to this
is that the service desk

383
00:20:16.310 --> 00:20:18.250
does it on behalf of the users.

384
00:20:18.250 --> 00:20:22.850
So, the service desk keeps up with
all the different request tools, and

385
00:20:22.850 --> 00:20:24.940
the user just provides over the phone or

386
00:20:24.940 --> 00:20:27.960
through an email the various
parameters for the request.

387
00:20:27.960 --> 00:20:30.340
And the service desk
executes on their behalf.

388
00:20:30.340 --> 00:20:31.910
That's not unusual.

389
00:20:31.910 --> 00:20:35.540
But keep in mind that the service
desk could be excluded,

390
00:20:35.540 --> 00:20:38.880
if you have some sort of other
interface with your users.

391
00:20:38.880 --> 00:20:39.380
Okay, all right.

392
00:20:42.520 --> 00:20:44.520
Certainly, inputs outputs
are straightforward,

393
00:20:44.520 --> 00:20:49.320
as well as potential integration
with other processes.

394
00:20:49.320 --> 00:20:51.580
Certainly, service level
management could be involved.

395
00:20:51.580 --> 00:20:56.077
Your service catalogue's gonna list the
list of services that could be requested,

396
00:20:56.077 --> 00:20:59.132
change management,
we have already talked about that.

397
00:20:59.132 --> 00:21:02.714
Incidence management, close to related,
access management, and

398
00:21:02.714 --> 00:21:04.391
financial management, also.

399
00:21:04.391 --> 00:21:06.499
We kinda talked about those
points of interfaces,

400
00:21:06.499 --> 00:21:09.860
we went through the discussion of
what kind of things can be requested.

401
00:21:09.860 --> 00:21:11.150
Sometimes, it is a request for

402
00:21:11.150 --> 00:21:15.940
access to particular assets, or
it requires financial approval.

403
00:21:15.940 --> 00:21:20.690
Right, that it could be using the same
system as incident management, right, etc.

404
00:21:20.690 --> 00:21:24.240
And certainly, using the same function,
the service desk.

405
00:21:24.240 --> 00:21:25.730
All right, very good.

406
00:21:25.730 --> 00:21:30.720
As we're getting to a point of review
here, looking at critical success

407
00:21:30.720 --> 00:21:34.980
factors in KPIs, again, as I've done with
the other processes, I wanna reinforce.

408
00:21:34.980 --> 00:21:38.370
I'm not gonna read these to you,
but I want to reinforce this idea.

409
00:21:38.370 --> 00:21:41.550
If you can read the CSS and KPIs and

410
00:21:41.550 --> 00:21:46.890
immediately assimilate what they mean,
and how it relates to this process, and

411
00:21:46.890 --> 00:21:52.120
you can understand immediately how
the KPIs support those critical factors.

412
00:21:52.120 --> 00:21:53.772
It's a great point of review, or

413
00:21:53.772 --> 00:21:56.136
validation that you
understand this process.

414
00:21:56.136 --> 00:22:01.232
So, I highly encourage you, as you begin
to review for any of these processes,

415
00:22:01.232 --> 00:22:05.811
you begin with an understanding of
a critical success factors in KPIs.

416
00:22:05.811 --> 00:22:09.385
If you drive through those,
you're going to find your weak spots, and

417
00:22:09.385 --> 00:22:12.710
you're also going to validate
your strengths, okay?

418
00:22:12.710 --> 00:22:14.940
So, that concludes our conversation
about request of film.

419
00:22:14.940 --> 00:22:16.500
There's a good self-study out there for
you.

420
00:22:16.500 --> 00:22:19.690
There's a couple, there's an exercise
later request to film it.

421
00:22:19.690 --> 00:22:23.356
And I mentioned these critical success
factors in KPIs as a good point of review.

422
00:22:23.356 --> 00:22:26.240
Of course, there is a discussion
form available for you, and

423
00:22:26.240 --> 00:22:27.969
must not forget the practice exams.

424
00:22:27.969 --> 00:22:33.294
The practice exams are also key to
help you prepare for the exam itself.

425
00:22:33.294 --> 00:22:36.538
>> All right, Terry, well, I don't think
there's anything I could add to that,

426
00:22:36.538 --> 00:22:37.983
I think he hit a home run on this one.

427
00:22:37.983 --> 00:22:42.340
We do appreciate in disseminating all
this wonderful information for us.

428
00:22:42.340 --> 00:22:45.810
So obviously, we can be even
better prepared for our OSA exam.

429
00:22:45.810 --> 00:22:49.900
But that being said, looks like it's that
time, yet again, for us to sign off.

430
00:22:49.900 --> 00:22:52.410
For ITPro.TV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

431
00:22:52.410 --> 00:22:53.300
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

432
00:22:53.300 --> 00:22:55.345
>> We'll see you next time.

433
00:22:55.345 --> 00:23:01.375
[MUSIC]

434
00:23:01.375 --> 00:23:03.325
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

30

So in that regard, highly important and

00:02:32.010 --> 00:02:34.490
>> Yeah, cuz you could be the best

So when you consider service operation

the value intended.

You're operating the service.

So in scope to do that in scope

So the scope is broad.

That is also important.

00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:09.720
Of course your service

IT management defines five.

If you go to ITIL operations, service

67
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:20.780
We are going to be diving into

00:03:20.780 --> 00:03:23.980
It also,
is necessarily managing the technology.

00:03:23.980 --> 00:03:24.500
Right?

Servers need patching.

00:03:26.160 --> 00:03:27.940
Networks need updated.

00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:30.480
You need security in play.

technology management, and

00:04:07.850 --> 00:04:11.737
So the scope of service

86
00:04:11.737 --> 00:04:14.380
And when you talk about the functions,
it's also deep.

87
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:17.350

you make sure that they have
the appropriate strategies,

89

that they're well designed,
that they're transition and tested well.

90
00:04:24.420 --> 00:04:27.780

operations we're gonna talk about a group

00:04:27.780 --> 00:04:32.510
of people or groups of people that
actually have their fingers in the pie

00:04:32.510 --> 00:04:35.310
up through the life cycle stages as well.

Okay, so a rather broad scope.

94

All right, now the value.

95

00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:48.900

Are they able to do something faster?

100
00:04:52.990 --> 00:04:57.239

00:04:57.239 --> 00:05:01.497
Can they have fewer regulatory

00:05:01.497 --> 00:05:04.710

103
00:05:04.710 --> 00:05:06.870
What is the business trying to get done?

104
00:05:06.870 --> 00:05:10.820
Faster, better, stronger,
what's the business trying to do?

105
00:05:10.820 --> 00:05:14.180
In service operations,
that's when that value is realized, right?

106
00:05:14.180 --> 00:05:19.340
So the business outcomes peppered
with a high dose of preferences and

00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:24.000
perceptions is gonna be driving the value

112

113

If you designed a well functioning
application that's not available,

114

then their perception are is,
well it's slow, right.

115
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:48.600
Maybe all the functionality is there,

116
00:05:48.600 --> 00:05:51.370
maybe they can do better
then they did before, but

117
00:05:51.370 --> 00:05:56.400
if they perceive it as being slow,

118
00:05:56.400 --> 00:06:00.290
Their perception is reality
in terms of the business.

119
00:06:00.290 --> 00:06:03.170
Now that doesn't mean
the customer's always right.

120
00:06:03.170 --> 00:06:06.130
It just means you have to manage
those perceptions, all right?

121
00:06:06.130 --> 00:06:10.430
So if they think it's slow, let's
make sure we understand what slow is.

122
00:06:10.430 --> 00:06:10.990
Right?

123
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:15.460
If they're trying to run a query

129
00:06:29.627 --> 00:06:34.486

131

132

133

139
00:07:04.334 --> 00:07:07.412
I mean, literally that could
be something measured but

Well let's get that from 10 rings

00:07:13.545 --> 00:07:15.270
Right, you can monitor

143

144
00:07:21.280 --> 00:07:23.762
Or better services of
phone doesn't even ring.

145
00:07:23.762 --> 00:07:27.447
I mean long term improvements
are certainly in the scopes of

146
00:07:27.447 --> 00:07:31.600
Service Operations as well as
the day to day improvements.

147
00:07:31.600 --> 00:07:33.520
So when you consider a methodology for

148
00:07:33.520 --> 00:07:37.276
improvement of the service operations,
you should consider a methodology of

149
00:07:37.276 --> 00:07:42.860
improvement that considers both time
frames, both long term and short term.

150
00:07:42.860 --> 00:07:47.530
As we take these concepts that we just
talked about in service operations

00:07:47.530 --> 00:07:52.490
forward, and to looking at
the details of individual processes

it's necessary to keep coming back and

153

That we will measure performance,

154
00:07:58.380 --> 00:08:02.990
that will do so
in a business relevant way right?

155

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry go over what you need to know about Access Management for the ITIL OSA exam. They discuss exactly what is Access Management. Then they get into "Why Access Management", basic concepts like Access, Identity, Rights, Services, and Directory Services. Finally they explain Access Management sources, verification of requests, and monitoring status.
episodes.title: Access Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.553
Welcome to ITPro.TV,

2
00:00:03.553 --> 00:00:08.304
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.304 --> 00:00:12.064
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.064 --> 00:00:13.978
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:16.476 --> 00:00:18.482
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

7

8
00:00:23.170 --> 00:00:26.600
That's right, and joining us back in the
studio is our good friend and mentor, Mr.

9
00:00:26.600 --> 00:00:27.420
Terry Decker.

10
00:00:27.420 --> 00:00:28.910
Terry, welcome back, man, how's it going?

11
00:00:28.910 --> 00:00:30.530
>> Daniel, happy to be here.

12

ITIL Operational Support Analysis and

processes in previous episodes.

14

15

Problem management, event management,

16

17

18
00:00:45.750 --> 00:00:50.675
And it is a process that is generally

students because we deal

21

22

23

24
00:01:00.990 --> 00:01:03.160
You get things because you log on.

25
00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:06.460
Some things you don't get access to
because you don't have the right level of

26
00:01:06.460 --> 00:01:07.680
permissions right.

27
00:01:07.680 --> 00:01:10.028
It's all based on managing
your identity and

28
00:01:10.028 --> 00:01:13.790

29
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:16.500
While keeping those people that
aren't supposed to have access

00:01:16.500 --> 00:01:18.250
away from those things right.

31
00:01:18.250 --> 00:01:20.880
So that's the ultimately

32

I think we just need to expand just

that we're talking about IT service
management as opposed to a solution.

keep in mind that giving access to

00:01:45.860 --> 00:01:50.790
Imagine this your TV,
cable TV provider, as an example.

39
00:01:50.790 --> 00:01:54.210
You certainly have a set top box and

00:01:54.210 --> 00:01:56.900
you have, perhaps that's how
you get your permissions.

41
00:01:56.900 --> 00:02:00.118

00:02:00.118 --> 00:02:03.318
So the cable's connected to
the back of your TV or to a box and

00:02:03.318 --> 00:02:05.010
it comes into your house.

44
00:02:05.010 --> 00:02:09.192
But how is it controlled as to
what you get to view, right?

45
00:02:09.192 --> 00:02:13.954
If you have a pay per view option,
then you get to view it when you pay or

46
00:02:13.954 --> 00:02:16.102
when you agree to pay, right?

47
00:02:16.102 --> 00:02:19.580
If you don't have the pay per view option,
then you don't get the chance to do that.

48
00:02:19.580 --> 00:02:21.530
If you haven't subscribed to HBO or

49
00:02:21.530 --> 00:02:24.240
the premium channels,
you don't get access to them.

50
00:02:24.240 --> 00:02:28.150
Now again, it's not because
they've granted you, as a person,

00:02:28.150 --> 00:02:29.260

00:02:29.260 --> 00:02:32.450

00:02:32.450 --> 00:02:37.770
They've given you a particular identity to
that set top box or that sort of thing.

54
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:42.731
Service access management is perhaps
a little bit different concept than

55
00:02:42.731 --> 00:02:45.750
user access management in some context.

56
00:02:45.750 --> 00:02:48.491
So just remember to keep
the box fairly open and

57
00:02:48.491 --> 00:02:51.460
fairly big when you
consider access management.

58
00:02:52.530 --> 00:02:55.230
Anyway, why bother with access management.

59
00:02:55.230 --> 00:02:58.770
I know, my friend Daniel here is
involved in some security courses.

60
00:02:58.770 --> 00:03:00.300
He's trying to figure
out how to get around

61
00:03:01.490 --> 00:03:04.980
some security ideas with a penetration
testing course coming up soon, so,

62
00:03:04.980 --> 00:03:09.000
what does access management mean to,
why do it?

63
00:03:09.000 --> 00:03:09.984
>> Why do Access Management?

64
00:03:09.984 --> 00:03:12.741
>> Yeah.
>> Because you don't want the wrong people

65
00:03:12.741 --> 00:03:14.601

66
00:03:14.601 --> 00:03:19.465
Even innocuously, there' s something that
they wouldn't think to do purposely to

67
00:03:19.465 --> 00:03:21.298
hurt you unmaliciously.

68
00:03:21.298 --> 00:03:24.060
They could still possibly hurt you

69
00:03:24.060 --> 00:03:27.000
if they have access to things
they just don't need access to.

70
00:03:27.000 --> 00:03:31.480
If Terry is a what does he need
access to our back up systems?

71
00:03:31.480 --> 00:03:34.760
Nothing.
He's gonna manage a database, and

72
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:38.720
I'm the backup administrator,
he can come in trying to be helpful,

73
00:03:38.720 --> 00:03:41.260
yeah I think I saw this cool command for
our backups, and

00:03:41.260 --> 00:03:42.820
he wipes out all our backups and
they're gone.

75
00:03:42.820 --> 00:03:45.000
Accidentally did it,
didn't do it maliciously, but

76
00:03:45.000 --> 00:03:48.930
he doesn't need that access to that so
we don't give it to him.

77
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:53.570
It's foundational to
security in any IT system.

78
00:03:53.570 --> 00:03:55.980
>> Very good, thanks,
Daniel, and a good segue.

79
00:03:55.980 --> 00:04:00.690
This is, indeed, a operational
extension of security management.

80
00:04:00.690 --> 00:04:02.730

process for the given services.

83
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:13.290

is designed into services.

84
00:04:13.290 --> 00:04:17.490
Access management is the operational
extension of that process to make

85
00:04:17.490 --> 00:04:22.150
sure that you're granting the right people
on a day to day basis what they need.

86
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:22.710
So, good.

87
00:04:22.710 --> 00:04:26.539
That also weighs into
the whole idea of governance.

88
