00:17:31.500 --> 00:17:32.650
A nice way.

323
00:17:32.650 --> 00:17:34.800
So, let's have a look at this.

324
00:17:34.800 --> 00:17:38.301
Of course,
access management is involved across and

325
00:17:38.301 --> 00:17:41.658
cross-pollinates with
lots of other processes.

326
00:17:41.658 --> 00:17:46.448
Certainly, information security management
is probably the most direct link.

327
00:17:46.448 --> 00:17:49.510
Access management is the operational
extension of information security

328
00:17:49.510 --> 00:17:51.000
management.

329
00:17:51.000 --> 00:17:55.190
Service catalog management could be part
of it because service catalog is going to

330
00:17:55.190 --> 00:17:58.830
describe how you access the service,
right?

331
00:17:58.830 --> 00:18:03.640
Which could just simply mean how you
request access to the service, all right?

332
00:18:03.640 --> 00:18:07.940
So service catalog management's gonna have
those indications of how someone would

333
00:18:07.940 --> 00:18:09.642
access the service, all right?

334
00:18:09.642 --> 00:18:12.476
Continuity management,
availability management,

335
00:18:12.476 --> 00:18:15.248
security management,
all related to making sure you

336
00:18:15.248 --> 00:18:19.328
are managing the appropriate numbers
of people, give them the right access.

337
00:18:19.328 --> 00:18:22.976
Demand management, how many users
should have access could be an issue.

338
00:18:22.976 --> 00:18:27.764
And you wanna make sure that perhaps
you can use access management as

339
00:18:27.764 --> 00:18:30.957
the way to throttle demand, right, etc.?

340
00:18:30.957 --> 00:18:34.909
Service asset configuration
management is gonna produce the CMS,

341
00:18:34.909 --> 00:18:37.274
the Configuration Management System.

342
00:18:37.274 --> 00:18:43.130
Which is gonna identify all the CIs that
may be in scope of access management.

343
00:18:43.130 --> 00:18:45.990
For instance, the servers,
the databases, etc.

344
00:18:45.990 --> 00:18:46.870
So it's gonna have their names,

345
00:18:46.870 --> 00:18:49.850
their attributes,
perhaps their security models in place.

346
00:18:49.850 --> 00:18:53.220
Are they using encrypted logons, etc.?

347
00:18:53.220 --> 00:18:54.010
Those types of things.

348
00:18:55.140 --> 00:18:58.030
Any of these, we talked about
request fulfillment already.

349
00:18:58.030 --> 00:18:58.970
Service level management.

350
00:18:58.970 --> 00:19:02.020
You certainly wanna measure this process.

351
00:19:02.020 --> 00:19:04.570
It could be a critical business area or

352
00:19:04.570 --> 00:19:08.530
business concern that access
is granted quickly, right?

353
00:19:08.530 --> 00:19:11.248
Maybe it's a real fluid system of access.

354
00:19:11.248 --> 00:19:15.024
I know I used to work and support clinical
trials at a pharmaceutical organization.

355
00:19:15.024 --> 00:19:19.555
And the moving parts of a clinical
trial is that patients came,

356
00:19:19.555 --> 00:19:21.360
patients left, right?

357
00:19:21.360 --> 00:19:25.521
And if a patient got there and couldn't
get access to the information right when

358
00:19:25.521 --> 00:19:29.650
they started, it was a very impactful
delay in these clinical trials.

359
00:19:29.650 --> 00:19:31.910
So access management was on a time clock.

360
00:19:31.910 --> 00:19:35.310
It's not that we're just gonna
get to it by the end of the week.

361
00:19:35.310 --> 00:19:36.750
So we kept time.

362
00:19:36.750 --> 00:19:38.992
How quickly are we resolving
these requests for

363
00:19:38.992 --> 00:19:41.230
access as it relates to clinical trials?

364
00:19:41.230 --> 00:19:44.820
And by keeping time,
you're effectively keeping score and

365
00:19:44.820 --> 00:19:48.420
therefore managing the effectiveness
of this process, right?

366
00:19:48.420 --> 00:19:53.010
So in some environments, access management
may need to be very, very fluid.

367
00:19:53.010 --> 00:19:55.234
Then therefore,
you might wanna put some targets and

368
00:19:55.234 --> 00:19:58.162
agree to those targets in your
service level agreements, all right?

369
00:19:58.162 --> 00:20:00.312
All right, very good.

370
00:20:00.312 --> 00:20:06.980
So, as you can imagine, as we've talked
about this process, it is challenging.

371
00:20:06.980 --> 00:20:12.100
How do you keep on going monitoring and
reporting on all access related activity?

372
00:20:12.100 --> 00:20:14.292
How do you know that
someone left the company?

373
00:20:14.292 --> 00:20:18.202
How do you go about finding which groups
they should be removed from, right?

374
00:20:18.202 --> 00:20:21.680
Now certainly access management can gain
you access to this through an appropriate

375
00:20:21.680 --> 00:20:23.100
directory service.

376
00:20:23.100 --> 00:20:28.014
But they also have to build into this
the process discipline to follow through.

377
00:20:28.014 --> 00:20:31.017
So when I left that company and
came back two years later and

378
00:20:31.017 --> 00:20:33.173
it still had all my permissions, right?

379
00:20:33.173 --> 00:20:35.933
So something was obviously
broken in that particular case.

380
00:20:35.933 --> 00:20:37.287
How it needed to be fixed?

381
00:20:37.287 --> 00:20:42.178
Was it interfaced between HR, who knew
I was leaving, and access management,

382
00:20:42.178 --> 00:20:46.740
who knows where all my permissions
have been spread out, right?

383
00:20:46.740 --> 00:20:50.570
So even knowing where all my permissions
were being spread out is not a easy

384
00:20:50.570 --> 00:20:52.260
concept to manage.

385
00:20:52.260 --> 00:20:54.630
Definitely a challenge,
right, you need to face.

386
00:20:54.630 --> 00:20:56.642
So access management is vitally important.

387
00:20:56.642 --> 00:20:58.958
I think, again, it's mostly intuitive.

388
00:20:58.958 --> 00:21:02.742
As this plays out on the exam,
you're gonna be looking for

389
00:21:02.742 --> 00:21:08.210
the value proposition of having a formal
process called access management.

390
00:21:08.210 --> 00:21:11.600
And that value proposition is centered
on the right people getting it,

391
00:21:11.600 --> 00:21:12.390
the wrong people not.

392
00:21:13.720 --> 00:21:17.240
And to be able to monitor that ongoing and
to do so quickly and

393
00:21:17.240 --> 00:21:19.730
responsively to business needs.

394
00:21:19.730 --> 00:21:21.609
That's what access managements all about.

395
00:21:21.609 --> 00:21:23.759
Hopefully you got that nice and neat.

396
00:21:23.759 --> 00:21:25.015
There's great places to go.

397
00:21:25.015 --> 00:21:29.139
As a reminder, just remember, have
a look at the critical success factors.

398
00:21:29.139 --> 00:21:32.288
And the KPIs as a I've talked
about on these other processes.

399
00:21:32.288 --> 00:21:35.008
Coming here to critical
success factors and

400
00:21:35.008 --> 00:21:38.618
KPIs as your first point of
review could be very valuable.

401
00:21:38.618 --> 00:21:42.776
Put another way, if you can read
the critical success factors and

402
00:21:42.776 --> 00:21:45.735
understand clearly what they're pointing.

403
00:21:45.735 --> 00:21:47.400
And you can read the KPIs and

404
00:21:47.400 --> 00:21:51.200
know how they support those
critical success factors.

405
00:21:51.200 --> 00:21:54.270
You are a very good place of
understanding this process, and

406
00:21:54.270 --> 00:21:56.180
may not need any further review.

407
00:21:56.180 --> 00:22:00.490
If, however, it reveals some fogginess, or
not quite clear on this, that concept or

408
00:22:00.490 --> 00:22:01.520
that concept,

409
00:22:01.520 --> 00:22:04.710
it can also point to the areas of
reinforcement you need to take on.

410
00:22:05.960 --> 00:22:09.280
And with that said,
one final note on Access Management.

411
00:22:10.340 --> 00:22:14.630
There's a Directed Self Study available
in the exercise that you can download.

412
00:22:14.630 --> 00:22:19.050
This is for you to go in and
reinforce this learning.

413
00:22:19.050 --> 00:22:23.570
You get your hands on some scenarios and
remember those practice exams as well.

414
00:22:23.570 --> 00:22:26.390
The practice exams
are probably your best source

415
00:22:26.390 --> 00:22:29.020
of reinforcing all we're
learning through OSA.

416
00:22:29.020 --> 00:22:31.130
As a way to not only
reinforce your learning, but

417
00:22:31.130 --> 00:22:33.880
get into the minds of
the testmaker a little bit.

418
00:22:33.880 --> 00:22:35.294
That's it for Access Management.

419
00:22:35.294 --> 00:22:35.980
>> All right, Terry.

420
00:22:35.980 --> 00:22:38.486
I like the way you put that
the right people get access and

421
00:22:38.486 --> 00:22:39.667
the wrong people don't.

422
00:22:39.667 --> 00:22:42.380
That's basically what it boils
down to at the end of the day.

423
00:22:42.380 --> 00:22:46.390
Fantastic overview of that how that
looks inside of the ITIL OSA exam.

424
00:22:46.390 --> 00:22:49.490
Appreciate that, and also the resources
that are available for you.

425
00:22:49.490 --> 00:22:52.633
So solidify those concepts in your mind so
that when you take the exam,

426
00:22:52.633 --> 00:22:53.767
you're ready for that.

427
00:22:53.767 --> 00:22:55.003
Terry, thanks for joining us today.

428
00:22:55.003 --> 00:22:57.021
We appreciate you stopping by.

429
00:22:57.021 --> 00:22:59.337
We appreciate our viewers as well for
watching.

430
00:22:59.337 --> 00:23:01.863
But it is time to sign off for ITProTV.

431
00:23:01.863 --> 00:23:03.272
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

432
00:23:03.272 --> 00:23:04.074
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

433
00:23:04.074 --> 00:23:06.583
>> And we'll see you next time.

434
00:23:06.583 --> 00:23:12.462
[MUSIC]

435
00:23:12.462 --> 00:23:15.715
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry take a look at the Service Desk Function. They start by comparing the difference between Functions and Processes. Next, they define the Service Desk's job, objectives, and staffing considerations. Finally they explore performance measuring.
episodes.title: The Service Desk Function
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:02.932
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pizet.

2
00:00:02.932 --> 00:00:08.138
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.138 --> 00:00:11.820
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.820 --> 00:00:13.460
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

5
00:00:13.460 --> 00:00:16.720
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV

6
00:00:16.720 --> 00:00:18.089
>> I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:18.089 --> 00:00:22.276
And in today's episode we are continuing
on with more on our ITIL OSA series.

8
00:00:22.276 --> 00:00:23.041
And, of course,

9
00:00:23.041 --> 00:00:26.257
it would be like a day without sunshine
if we didn't have the good man back.

10
00:00:26.257 --> 00:00:27.740
His name, Mr. Terry Decker.

11
00:00:27.740 --> 00:00:29.920
Terry, welcome back, sir,
we're so glad to have you again.

12
00:00:29.920 --> 00:00:32.920
>> Glad to be here shining light,
pretty cool.

13
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:36.280
Well, we've had a pretty good journey so
far in our previous episodes.

14
00:00:36.280 --> 00:00:38.986
We went through five processes,
incident management,

15
00:00:38.986 --> 00:00:42.440
access management, problem management,
request fulfillment and event management.

16
00:00:42.440 --> 00:00:46.490
Not quite in that order, but
we did go through those five processes.

17
00:00:46.490 --> 00:00:48.620
And again we looked at
operational support and analysis.

18
00:00:48.620 --> 00:00:53.070
We also looked into how you go about
uplifting those processes through

19
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:55.555
good designs and good methodologies.

20
00:00:55.555 --> 00:00:59.160
Well, who gets that done,
who makes that happen?

21
00:00:59.160 --> 00:01:01.680
Now, we're gonna move on to functions.

22
00:01:01.680 --> 00:01:05.500
And we're gonna start, if you look at
the slide here, we're gonna start with

23
00:01:05.500 --> 00:01:09.390
characterizing the difference
between a function and a process.

24
00:01:09.390 --> 00:01:14.490
Functions are groups of people or
whole departments that they actually

25
00:01:14.490 --> 00:01:18.497
do the work that happens in IT operations,
right.

26
00:01:18.497 --> 00:01:20.120
I abbreviate this.

27
00:01:20.120 --> 00:01:23.137
Functions are groups of people with
special tools and skills, right.

28
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:28.670
So your network experts live here,
your application experts live here.

29
00:01:28.670 --> 00:01:33.160
Your day to day grind of IT happens here,
right.

30
00:01:33.160 --> 00:01:37.390
Processes are, again, those predefined,
structured set of activities.

31
00:01:37.390 --> 00:01:39.220
And we certainly have
talked about activities.

32
00:01:39.220 --> 00:01:41.910
We talked about five of
these here recently, right.

33
00:01:41.910 --> 00:01:46.400
So processes tend to be documents
in the background, right.

34
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:48.280
People are the ones that
actually execute it.

35
00:01:48.280 --> 00:01:50.760
They touch physical devices.

36
00:01:50.760 --> 00:01:52.510
They maintain servers.

37
00:01:52.510 --> 00:01:56.270
They fill up generators to keep the power
supplies or the power management

38
00:01:57.350 --> 00:02:00.980
systems up and running when there's
a power failure at the data center, right.

39
00:02:00.980 --> 00:02:03.725
They manage cooling systems,
they have wiring closets, right.

40
00:02:03.725 --> 00:02:08.400
It's the physical assets as well as things
you touch, the tools that are touched,

41
00:02:08.400 --> 00:02:13.350
the dashboards that are manipulated,
the reports that are made, etc.

42
00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:15.040
So the functions are where the people are.

43
00:02:16.430 --> 00:02:18.100
All through our journey of ITIL,

44
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:21.280
even back in foundation when we
talked about service strategy,

45
00:02:21.280 --> 00:02:26.030
service design, service transition and
now here at service operations, even then,

46
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:31.660
we talked about processes and
the 26 processes that ITIL defines.

47
00:02:31.660 --> 00:02:36.017
These processes are actually practiced,
developed, put into life,

48
00:02:36.017 --> 00:02:40.603
they work or not, because you have
special people managing them, right.

49
00:02:40.603 --> 00:02:41.374
And the tools and

50
00:02:41.374 --> 00:02:45.210
the technology work because you
have special people managing them.

51
00:02:45.210 --> 00:02:48.770
The collection of all this technology,
the products, the tools and

52
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:52.670
the processes form the services
underpinning everything.

53
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:54.330
This is where the people are.

54
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:56.770
So what we're gonna be doing first
is going over to the service desk,

55
00:02:56.770 --> 00:02:59.370
a very special group of people, right.

56
00:02:59.370 --> 00:03:01.860
The service desk is a dedicated
staff responsible for

57
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:05.200
dealing with the issues and
requests that come in from users.

58
00:03:05.200 --> 00:03:06.885
Single point of contact.

59
00:03:06.885 --> 00:03:11.620
ITIL, again, has a strong
predisposition for this word, single.

60
00:03:11.620 --> 00:03:14.060
Now, we talked about incident management,
and

61
00:03:14.060 --> 00:03:17.890
we talked about how the service could be
at the front end of incident management.

62
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:19.710
We also talked about
request fulfillment and

63
00:03:19.710 --> 00:03:24.920
how it can be on the front end
of request fulfillment, right.

64
00:03:24.920 --> 00:03:28.730
So service desk can be in front
of both of those processes.

65
00:03:28.730 --> 00:03:33.353
But the function is the group of people,
the processes are what they are, right.

66
00:03:33.353 --> 00:03:37.800
So certainly, when you consider
the service desk, it's vitally important.

67
00:03:37.800 --> 00:03:40.945
As a single point of
contact with the end users,

68
00:03:40.945 --> 00:03:44.339
it can make a bad service
look pretty good, right.

69
00:03:44.339 --> 00:03:46.448
Having good incident
management processes and

70
00:03:46.448 --> 00:03:48.879
good request fulfillment
processes are part of this.

71
00:03:48.879 --> 00:03:52.807
But having good people with the right
demeanor, the right technical acumen,

72
00:03:52.807 --> 00:03:56.300
the right customer service
acumen is very valuable.

73
00:03:56.300 --> 00:04:00.329
Once upon a time at ITIL, back in
the early days of ITIL, I think they

74
00:04:00.329 --> 00:04:05.212
recognized that, this is late 80s,
early 90s, when they were first writing

75
00:04:05.212 --> 00:04:09.568
these books, making a justification for
a service desk was necessary.

76
00:04:09.568 --> 00:04:14.255
So there's a lot of verbiage in the ITIL
library related to the value of

77
00:04:14.255 --> 00:04:19.507
the service desk, as if you need to sell
this to people to understand, right.

78
00:04:19.507 --> 00:04:24.160
I think it's probably a bit less urgent to
sell people on the value of a service desk

79
00:04:24.160 --> 00:04:25.200
these days.

80
00:04:25.200 --> 00:04:28.350
Most people recognize the value of having

81
00:04:28.350 --> 00:04:32.020
a group of people that can face
users on a day to day basis.

82
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:33.620
You're not bothering your second and

83
00:04:33.620 --> 00:04:37.140
third tier support people as much
because they're handling the day to day.

84
00:04:37.140 --> 00:04:39.870
That's one of the values
to the IT provider.

85
00:04:39.870 --> 00:04:42.930
And you're also providing value
to the customers because they

86
00:04:42.930 --> 00:04:47.480
have a single place to go, and
a known, single place to go,

87
00:04:47.480 --> 00:04:51.760
instead of saying, well, who do I call for
this or who do I call for that, right?

88
00:04:51.760 --> 00:04:53.230
They know they go to the service desk.

89
00:04:53.230 --> 00:04:55.945
So you're streamlining
the customer experience.

90
00:04:55.945 --> 00:05:01.010
You're also streamlining the IT service
provider's experiences, as well.

91
00:05:01.010 --> 00:05:03.028
So the service desk is
a value proposition.

92
00:05:03.028 --> 00:05:05.900
It may be overwrought now,
I think most people get it.

93
00:05:05.900 --> 00:05:08.890
But keep in mind that ITIL
have been around long enough

94
00:05:08.890 --> 00:05:12.210
that they probably had to preach the value
of service desk long ago, right.

95
00:05:14.270 --> 00:05:17.390
So, again, that's why we consider
the justification for it.

96
00:05:17.390 --> 00:05:19.200
So what is the service desk trying to do?

97
00:05:19.200 --> 00:05:22.820
We've talked about the processes,
incident request fulfillment.

98
00:05:22.820 --> 00:05:26.660
Being on the front end of those two
processes means the service desk has

99
00:05:26.660 --> 00:05:29.640
the same objectives as those processes.

100
00:05:29.640 --> 00:05:32.420
Consider that the objective of
incident management is to restore

101
00:05:32.420 --> 00:05:34.650
service as quickly as possible.

102
00:05:34.650 --> 00:05:36.020
True, right.

103
00:05:36.020 --> 00:05:40.380
As a process incident
management is on point for

104
00:05:40.380 --> 00:05:42.720
restoring service as quickly as possible.

105
00:05:42.720 --> 00:05:48.020
As a practitioner of the incident
management process, these people at

106
00:05:48.020 --> 00:05:53.220
the service desk are also responsible for
restoring services as quickly as possible.

107
00:05:53.220 --> 00:05:54.410
Same with requests.

108
00:05:54.410 --> 00:05:55.840
Request fulfillment,

109
00:05:55.840 --> 00:06:00.970
making sure you have a methodical way to
respond to requests for standard services.

110
00:06:00.970 --> 00:06:05.250
Here the service desk, making sure
that that is well done, efficiently,

111
00:06:05.250 --> 00:06:08.380
effectively, completely logged, right.

112
00:06:08.380 --> 00:06:09.975
So you see the idea here.

113
00:06:09.975 --> 00:06:14.320
As a service desk, you are perhaps
the canary in the coal mine.

114
00:06:14.320 --> 00:06:17.935
You'll know first if there's problems
in the infrastructure, potentially.

115
00:06:17.935 --> 00:06:22.040
Event management can kinda bolster that
by giving you some back end indicators,

116
00:06:22.040 --> 00:06:23.990
and monitoring certainly can, as well.

117
00:06:23.990 --> 00:06:26.850
But the service desk could actually
be your canary in a coal mine for

118
00:06:26.850 --> 00:06:30.071
lots of user-based issues, okay.

119
00:06:30.071 --> 00:06:33.218
All right, how do you go about
staffing your service desk?

120
00:06:33.218 --> 00:06:35.158
Tough question.

121
00:06:37.849 --> 00:06:44.602
The ebb and flow of incidents
is definitely variable, right.

122
00:06:44.602 --> 00:06:46.450
If you've just lost a brand new service,

123
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:49.100
you can anticipate levels
are going to be high.

124
00:06:49.100 --> 00:06:52.050
If you have a data center melt down,
you're gonna have a lot of incidence,

125
00:06:52.050 --> 00:06:54.590
right, because you're affecting
lots of different services.

126
00:06:54.590 --> 00:06:58.060
So making sure you have the correct
number of staff to master the man levels

127
00:06:58.060 --> 00:07:00.420
is a tough thing to do.

128
00:07:00.420 --> 00:07:03.720
There's certainly options out there.

129
00:07:03.720 --> 00:07:05.565
There's help desk institutes,

130
00:07:05.565 --> 00:07:08.940
here's all sort of things that help
you with some formulas for doing this.

131
00:07:08.940 --> 00:07:11.650
ITIL doesn't go into
the details of those at all.

132
00:07:11.650 --> 00:07:14.300
Monitoring the performance
of your service desk,

133
00:07:14.300 --> 00:07:16.870
by monitoring the performance
of request fulfillment and

134
00:07:16.870 --> 00:07:21.237
incident management, can help with
the staffing levels, for sure, right.

135
00:07:22.780 --> 00:07:25.820
Factors for consideration is
the capacity of your phone systems,

136
00:07:25.820 --> 00:07:28.560
the capacity of your business,
how many users you have.

137
00:07:28.560 --> 00:07:29.840
What's the geographic spread, right?

138
00:07:30.870 --> 00:07:35.750
How often do you reintroduce services or
bring new services into the environment?

139
00:07:35.750 --> 00:07:36.820
Those types of things.

140
00:07:36.820 --> 00:07:42.610
So this is not a best practice of
how to manage staffing levels.

141
00:07:42.610 --> 00:07:45.910
But, certainly,
it's a challenge you face in terms of

142
00:07:46.960 --> 00:07:49.930
having the right number of people in
the right place at the right time, okay.

143
00:07:51.360 --> 00:07:53.740
So to give you an idea here.

144
00:07:53.740 --> 00:07:55.815
What's your goals in an organization?

145
00:07:55.815 --> 00:08:00.530
Do you have a goal where you want most of
your tickets resolved at the front end

146
00:08:00.530 --> 00:08:02.550
by the first line by the service desk?

147
00:08:02.550 --> 00:08:07.010
Or are they more of a call routing
kind of service desk, right?

148
00:08:07.010 --> 00:08:09.420
You might be some point in between, right.

149
00:08:09.420 --> 00:08:13.835
Certainly there could be a lot of value
driven by having highly skilled people in

150
00:08:13.835 --> 00:08:19.080
front of your users so
you can resolve those issues quickly.

151
00:08:19.080 --> 00:08:20.690
But if you have a very
diverse environment,

152
00:08:20.690 --> 00:08:24.470
with lots of specialized skills behind
you, then maybe the best way your service

153
00:08:24.470 --> 00:08:27.811
desk can serve the organization is
just to do the appropriate routing,

154
00:08:27.811 --> 00:08:30.370
right, to get it to the right
people at the right time.

155
00:08:30.370 --> 00:08:35.230
So depending on your general strategy for
fulfillment, do you want it being resolved

156
00:08:35.230 --> 00:08:39.620
at the first level, at the maximum level,
then you're going to staff accordingly.

157
00:08:39.620 --> 00:08:43.674
If it's more call routing, then perhaps
you even automate some of that, right.

158
00:08:43.674 --> 00:08:47.840
I know I certainly have made those
calls where I get the call tree, right.

159
00:08:47.840 --> 00:08:50.550
I get the call tree, and
I get routed to a person that can help me.

160
00:08:50.550 --> 00:08:52.247
Is it a billing issue, right?

161
00:08:52.247 --> 00:08:54.220
I get routed to the billing department.

162
00:08:54.220 --> 00:08:55.840
Is it a service issue?

163
00:08:55.840 --> 00:08:57.670
Over that way, that sort of thing.

164
00:08:57.670 --> 00:09:00.550
And I quickly want to find the zero
to get me to an operator because

165
00:09:00.550 --> 00:09:01.710
my question is not either one of those.

166
00:09:01.710 --> 00:09:03.515
I totally get that challenge,
as well, right.

167
00:09:03.515 --> 00:09:04.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> You get that idea.

168
00:09:04.630 --> 00:09:05.769
I was on a call tree the other day.

169
00:09:05.769 --> 00:09:09.360
It had nine choices, and
no option to say just give me an operator,

170
00:09:09.360 --> 00:09:11.900
tell me which choice I'm supposed to use.

171
00:09:11.900 --> 00:09:13.950
None of the nine sounded
like what I needed.

172
00:09:13.950 --> 00:09:17.790
So if you want to set up
some sort of call tree or

173
00:09:17.790 --> 00:09:20.860
routing, you gotta make sure it's
intuitive and effective, right.

174
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:24.640
So to mention a negative example is also
to mention some of the challenges of

175
00:09:24.640 --> 00:09:27.320
managing a service desk and
service provision effectively.

176
00:09:27.320 --> 00:09:31.450
>> It's funny, some of those automated
call trees definitely seem like their job

177
00:09:31.450 --> 00:09:34.180
is to get you to no one effectively.

178
00:09:35.940 --> 00:09:37.762
Maybe if we just route this guy
through 20 different spots,

179
00:09:37.762 --> 00:09:38.719
he'll just give up and hang up.

180
00:09:38.719 --> 00:09:40.558
>> [LAUGH] That's right, that's right.

181
00:09:40.558 --> 00:09:42.006
Hey, we didn't have any
problems this week.

182
00:09:42.006 --> 00:09:44.690
>> It does seem to have that effect,
it really does.

183
00:09:44.690 --> 00:09:46.750
I think that's really interesting
if you keep that going or

184
00:09:46.750 --> 00:09:48.340
keep that thought going.

185
00:09:48.340 --> 00:09:53.330
If you have nine choices
in a call tree and try

186
00:09:53.330 --> 00:09:58.590
to get the right routing, and you have
a number of people that always press zero,

187
00:09:58.590 --> 00:10:00.150
then your call tree's not
really helping too much.

188
00:10:00.150 --> 00:10:02.910
So you need to figure that out,
figure out what that balance is.

189
00:10:02.910 --> 00:10:04.975
And if you don't give them
that zero option, my gosh,

190
00:10:04.975 --> 00:10:06.880
you're really just gonna
have screaming users.

191
00:10:06.880 --> 00:10:07.620
They don't call anymore.

192
00:10:07.620 --> 00:10:10.170
So that's the interesting
thing about these metrics.

193
00:10:10.170 --> 00:10:14.450
Just because you have a reduction
in metrics, or reduction in things,

194
00:10:14.450 --> 00:10:15.950
does that mean you're getting better?

195
00:10:15.950 --> 00:10:17.790
We'll have a look at that
a little bit later on.

196
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:22.420
But certainly measuring
service desk capabilities, or

197
00:10:22.420 --> 00:10:26.110
measuring their performance,
is somewhat of a subset

198
00:10:26.110 --> 00:10:30.380
from measuring just simply raw, incident
data and raw, request fulfillment data.

199
00:10:30.380 --> 00:10:33.880
You need to have some finesse on
that measurement piece, right.

200
00:10:33.880 --> 00:10:38.390
So considering measurement, good segue to
that, what are you trying to measure for

201
00:10:38.390 --> 00:10:39.150
the service desk?

202
00:10:41.650 --> 00:10:44.380
The health and maturity of
the process is underneath them.

203
00:10:44.380 --> 00:10:47.070
The health and maturity of
the service desk at large, right.

204
00:10:47.070 --> 00:10:53.190
If you had a service
desk that's primary aim

205
00:10:53.190 --> 00:10:58.470
is to route appropriately, and
not try to solve anything, then probably

206
00:10:58.470 --> 00:11:02.420
your measurements are gonna be related
on did you route it correctly, right?

207
00:11:02.420 --> 00:11:03.508
Pretty simple.

208
00:11:03.508 --> 00:11:06.770
However, if you've pushed out to
the service desk the responsibility

209
00:11:06.770 --> 00:11:08.770
to resolve a lot of your incidents,

210
00:11:08.770 --> 00:11:11.492
then incident resolution time
might be part of it, right.

211
00:11:11.492 --> 00:11:15.800
And then you wanna monitor the number
of tickets that had to be sent back

212
00:11:15.800 --> 00:11:19.170
to second and third level support,
to get that kind of nuance, right.

213
00:11:19.170 --> 00:11:21.590
So you're talking about
first line resolution or

214
00:11:21.590 --> 00:11:24.900
the average time to resolve incidents,
these are measurable, right.

215
00:11:24.900 --> 00:11:26.700
And you're not just
measuring the processes.

216
00:11:26.700 --> 00:11:32.225
You're measuring the process as executed
by the service desk, of course.

217
00:11:32.225 --> 00:11:33.364
So a little bit of nuance there.

218
00:11:33.364 --> 00:11:38.138
So it's good to have this idea that
metrics may not equal the reality

219
00:11:38.138 --> 00:11:39.765
that you perceive.

220
00:11:39.765 --> 00:11:41.580
Look at this first example on the left.

221
00:11:41.580 --> 00:11:44.685
You had a decrease in
incidents of 25% last month.

222
00:11:44.685 --> 00:11:49.174
So is the assumption that you have
better service desk performance

223
00:11:49.174 --> 00:11:52.550
because there's not as many incidents,
right?

224
00:11:54.220 --> 00:11:55.404
Well, you have that assumption.

225
00:11:55.404 --> 00:11:58.716
But last month 200 staff moved to a
different company as part of a merger, and

226
00:11:58.716 --> 00:12:01.120
their calls are no longer
received at our service desk.

227
00:12:01.120 --> 00:12:03.870
So you had a reduction in staff,
people aren't calling anymore, right.

228
00:12:03.870 --> 00:12:08.899
Or maybe the reason why it was such
a big drop is that last month was

229
00:12:08.899 --> 00:12:14.781
the first month after six months of
escalating incident volumes, right.

230
00:12:14.781 --> 00:12:16.540
You can't take these in a vacuum.

231
00:12:16.540 --> 00:12:18.460
For instance, another one,
incident resolution time.

232
00:12:18.460 --> 00:12:21.490
So not just the volume, but
now we got incident resolution time.

233
00:12:21.490 --> 00:12:24.710
Improved 10% last quarter.

234
00:12:24.710 --> 00:12:27.890
So that means you're resolving
them quicker, right?

235
00:12:27.890 --> 00:12:30.250
So your assumption is the service
desk is performing better.

236
00:12:31.400 --> 00:12:35.899
However, over that same quarter,
incident reactivations went up 70%.

237
00:12:38.030 --> 00:12:42.204
That came from my direct experience is
that we certainly changed behaviors at

238
00:12:42.204 --> 00:12:43.290
the service desk.

239
00:12:43.290 --> 00:12:44.830
We're gonna focus on resolution time.

240
00:12:44.830 --> 00:12:47.088
Make sure you get these things solved,
right,

241
00:12:47.088 --> 00:12:49.130
don't let them linger more than two days.

242
00:12:49.130 --> 00:12:50.280
Get them done, right.

243
00:12:50.280 --> 00:12:52.790
So people we're getting them done,
they were closing them down.

244
00:12:52.790 --> 00:12:53.910
So our metrics are looking really good.

245
00:12:55.210 --> 00:12:58.350
But we had a 70% increase in how
many of those we had to reopen

246
00:12:58.350 --> 00:12:59.840
because they weren't really solved.

247
00:12:59.840 --> 00:13:02.185
>> Right,
they just got the fire put out enough.

248
00:13:02.185 --> 00:13:03.905
>> Right.
>> To where the user was happy for

249
00:13:03.905 --> 00:13:04.500
the moment.

250
00:13:04.500 --> 00:13:08.480
And then as a soon as a wind came by,
it fanned the flame and it came back.

251
00:13:08.480 --> 00:13:10.708
>> Exactly, exactly right, good example.

252
00:13:10.708 --> 00:13:14.361
So, again, you need to have some metrics
that are in some balance, perhaps in some

253
00:13:14.361 --> 00:13:17.611
tension, with each other to make
sure you're accurately getting them.

254
00:13:17.611 --> 00:13:20.430
And also measurement over time.

255
00:13:20.430 --> 00:13:23.610
To say one month improvement or
one quarter improvement,

256
00:13:23.610 --> 00:13:26.250
you might need to have a broader time
horizon for some of these performance

257
00:13:26.250 --> 00:13:29.530
metrics to really gauge
the health of your service desk.

258
00:13:29.530 --> 00:13:33.858
A popular topic in the marketplace,

259
00:13:33.858 --> 00:13:39.160
that does happen pretty frequently,
is the outsourcing of the service desk.

260
00:13:39.160 --> 00:13:43.770
With the belief that outsourcing the
service desk for some generic activities

261
00:13:43.770 --> 00:13:48.230
can be done by folks that don't cost
as much and you can get more scale.

262
00:13:49.270 --> 00:13:53.250
The combination of lower cost
can give you more scale, and

263
00:13:53.250 --> 00:13:54.580
you can kinda accordion with that.

264
00:13:54.580 --> 00:13:57.153
So some service providers,
that's what their business is,

265
00:13:57.153 --> 00:13:58.495
we'll give you a service desk.

266
00:13:58.495 --> 00:14:02.962
And they sell a service desk to an
organization that outsources that service

267
00:14:02.962 --> 00:14:05.060
desk to the third party.

268
00:14:05.060 --> 00:14:06.320
Not a bad idea.

269
00:14:06.320 --> 00:14:11.560
ITIL certainly recognizes that it can be
an effective approach to cost savings and

270
00:14:11.560 --> 00:14:12.610
scale.

271
00:14:12.610 --> 00:14:16.090
At the same time,
you gotta maintain accountability.

272
00:14:16.090 --> 00:14:20.730
Even though you've outsourced it, it's
still your service that they are serving.

273
00:14:20.730 --> 00:14:24.280
So you gotta make sure that you have
accountability built in, and those levels

274
00:14:24.280 --> 00:14:29.280
of interface are opened, and those means
of interface are effective, right.

275
00:14:29.280 --> 00:14:32.450
You still wanna keep score, you wanna
measure your targets, you want to

276
00:14:32.450 --> 00:14:36.110
measure the success, you want to drive
improvements and keep it that way.

277
00:14:36.110 --> 00:14:39.600
I've certainly worked at organizations
that had a high proponent of outsource

278
00:14:39.600 --> 00:14:44.520
service desk technicians, where the vast
majority of them didn't work for

279
00:14:44.520 --> 00:14:45.230
our company, right.

280
00:14:45.230 --> 00:14:46.810
And it worked.

281
00:14:46.810 --> 00:14:49.140
It was very effective,
and we got the cost and

282
00:14:49.140 --> 00:14:52.303
we got the scale that we were looking for,
right.

283
00:14:52.303 --> 00:14:57.160
But we didn't get there until we also
built the good interfaces between

284
00:14:57.160 --> 00:15:00.660
that third party and us,
in terms of performance expectations.

285
00:15:00.660 --> 00:15:04.290
Penalties and rewards,
synergies across the interfaces, etc.

286
00:15:04.290 --> 00:15:06.810
How do you manage the feedback
from third tier and

287
00:15:06.810 --> 00:15:09.800
second tier support
back to the front desk?

288
00:15:09.800 --> 00:15:14.780
Before, it was a bit more informal, so
our knowledge base needed to grow up and

289
00:15:14.780 --> 00:15:16.000
be more mature.

290
00:15:16.000 --> 00:15:19.560
Our second and third tier support
had to be more forthright with

291
00:15:19.560 --> 00:15:21.740
passing on information to the front desk.

292
00:15:21.740 --> 00:15:22.360
Where it used to,

293
00:15:22.360 --> 00:15:25.230
it was just a phone call back to Johnny,
who you knew they'd answer.

294
00:15:25.230 --> 00:15:27.790
The service desk said thanks,
Johnny, I got it, right.

295
00:15:27.790 --> 00:15:31.082
That became unsustainable in a scale way.

296
00:15:31.082 --> 00:15:35.011
With a third party provider, we had to
provide more knowledge articles and write

297
00:15:35.011 --> 00:15:38.941
these things down because we don't wanna
be bothering Johnny with such things,

298
00:15:38.941 --> 00:15:40.030
right, etc.

299
00:15:40.030 --> 00:15:44.150
So, again, to recap, the service desk
is a vitally important function.

300
00:15:44.150 --> 00:15:47.160
ITIL certainly envisions it
as a single point of contact.

301
00:15:47.160 --> 00:15:49.820
They have a strong predisposition for

302
00:15:49.820 --> 00:15:52.265
the service desk being
a single point of contact.

303
00:15:52.265 --> 00:15:55.630
Now, that doesn't mean that you couldn't
have scenarios where you do have

304
00:15:55.630 --> 00:15:58.510
distribute the load, right.

305
00:15:58.510 --> 00:16:00.622
But they want the idea that
there's a single place to call.

306
00:16:00.622 --> 00:16:05.442
Even if you have geographically separated
people, that there's one place to call for

307
00:16:05.442 --> 00:16:09.206
the users, one web interface, or
the combination of a phone call or

308
00:16:09.206 --> 00:16:10.500
a web interface.

309
00:16:10.500 --> 00:16:13.570
They know they're calling
the service desk.

310
00:16:13.570 --> 00:16:17.010
And it might land in Amsterdam,
it might land in Philadelphia eventually.

311
00:16:17.010 --> 00:16:21.160
Wherever it might land, it's still
a single call for those users, right.

312
00:16:21.160 --> 00:16:22.800
So as you consider this on the exam,

313
00:16:22.800 --> 00:16:26.960
you're gonna consider things
like what's the cost?

314
00:16:26.960 --> 00:16:31.920
Is there a valuable reason to outsource
this for cost savings and scale?

315
00:16:31.920 --> 00:16:34.566
What if you are merging
seven companies and

316
00:16:34.566 --> 00:16:37.516
they each have their own service desk,
right?

317
00:16:37.516 --> 00:16:40.611
ITIL would certainly have
a strong predisposition for

318
00:16:40.611 --> 00:16:43.105
let's make that one service desk, right.

319
00:16:43.105 --> 00:16:46.300
This one was good, this wasn't so
good, that one was really great.

320
00:16:46.300 --> 00:16:48.360
Maybe you adopt that methodology and

321
00:16:48.360 --> 00:16:51.900
those processes while
uplifting the rest of them.

322
00:16:51.900 --> 00:16:55.220
That's the kind of approach you wanna look
at when you talk about an enterprise level

323
00:16:55.220 --> 00:16:58.960
service desk is how you build synergies,
how you build quality.

324
00:16:58.960 --> 00:17:02.190
And there's measurable quality and
continual improvement.

325
00:17:02.190 --> 00:17:04.580
That concludes it for
service desk, I'm gonna hope, yep.

326
00:17:04.580 --> 00:17:07.760
>> For someone who has actually
worked at a service desk, and

327
00:17:07.760 --> 00:17:12.680
has worked with service desks
as I've advanced in my career,

328
00:17:12.680 --> 00:17:15.454
I can tell you everything this
man just said is 100% correct.

329
00:17:15.454 --> 00:17:17.140
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because I've seen service desks that

330
00:17:17.140 --> 00:17:18.380
are horrible.

331
00:17:18.380 --> 00:17:20.870
And the reasons they're horrible is
because they don't follow the procedures,

332
00:17:20.870 --> 00:17:24.980
and the policies and
the ideas that Terry was giving us today.

333
00:17:24.980 --> 00:17:26.860
They could have used
a healthy dose of that, and

334
00:17:26.860 --> 00:17:28.210
things would have been
a whole lot smoother.

335
00:17:28.210 --> 00:17:31.400
And I'm sure you out there have
dealt with a service desk before,

336
00:17:31.400 --> 00:17:34.030
at least in some capacity, and you can

337
00:17:34.030 --> 00:17:38.105
really in a pragmatic way understand
how these things work out in reality.

338
00:17:38.105 --> 00:17:40.255
So, Terry, great job for us today.

339
00:17:40.255 --> 00:17:44.785
We thank you for explaining service
desks in the ITIL fashion for us.

340
00:17:44.785 --> 00:17:46.925
But it does look like we've come
to that portion of our show,

341
00:17:46.925 --> 00:17:48.825
that is the signing off portion.

342
00:17:48.825 --> 00:17:51.065
So that being said,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

343
00:17:51.065 --> 00:17:53.575
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

344
00:17:53.575 --> 00:17:54.325
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

345
00:17:54.325 --> 00:17:55.430
>> And we'll see you next time.

346
00:17:55.430 --> 00:18:02.958
[MUSIC]

347
00:18:02.958 --> 00:18:05.686
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:12:44.730 --> 00:12:45.720

00:14:22.840 --> 00:14:23.712

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Terry describe some of the technologies and their implementations used by Operational Support teams. This includes self-help tools like FAQs, Automated Request forms, and Reporting tools. Then they discuss which tools are used by which areas and tool requirements. Finally to take a look at methodology and best practices.
